2.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 mars 2022
Great visual experience.
Boring game.

Whether it's worth the money is subjective. If you liked the YouTube videos of this during development then I'd say sure, buy it. It's fun to experience this for yourself. But be patient, the game aspect of the software is tedious, at least to me. It's just a lot of aimless wandering through samey areas with a different coat of paint and a lot of fruitless interactions with samey NPCs. I feel like the wonder of a completely foreign world and presentation offered many chances for players to become curious how things work, how to interact with things, opportunities to guide and mislead players into thinking they understand the world now, only to reveal that they infact do not understand a thing. That did not really happen. The one thing the game really does well, is surprise the player how vast the world really is compared to what you see. That happens again and again. But exploring that vastness is sadly not enticing.

It's okay, really. Nothing is outright bad or repulsive, and the unfamiliar visual experience carries the rest of the game. I think I would have preferred a different format, maybe less story focused with NPCs and more sandboxy puzzles. Go get it, it's short and quick to get into. Then, if you feel like you got a bad deal, return it.
 
ruolbu

Recommandé
4.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 mars 2022
This is a rather lackluster experience for a game with such a premise - the writing is fine, I guess, though with too much redditness to it sometimes; the gameplay is nonexistent for the most part; the amount of pointless characters is evident from the get go; the interaction with them or items is disappointing; the main feature is not used as much it could have been; VR part has no smooth turning;

Just by reading that you'd think it deserves a thumb down, it does, however there are two major points that stop me from doing that:
1. it's an ambitious and very complex indie project that clearly took the majority of time to just make the math work on Unity, a lot of parts had to be rewritten from the scratch
2. the dev has promised to provide us with some mod tools that could help us utilize his amazing engine to create something of our own

Can't wait for those.

I was really looking forward to this game, but I ended up just extremely disappointed with it. Very little of the gameplay actually relies on the interesting geometry of the world, and what little does is either ridiculously tedious or ridiculously difficult. I feel like the game suffers from a lack of playtesting from people who aren't the developer, and a lack of difficulty balance as well.

The idea behind the game is great, and I loved following the developer's YouTube channel. But the resulting game just plain isn't fun.

This game had so much potential but it ended up just being a disappointment.

Évaluation publiée le 4 juillet 2022
Is this essentially just a tech demo? Yes. The "gameplay" here mostly consists of walking around and talking to NPCs, but the real thing this game is about is trying to wrap your head around a different reality. The challenges aren't really adrenaline-pumping tests of skill, they're carefully constructed ways of getting you to examine how your brain conceptualizes space. So yes, it's only a couple of hours of content that isn't very hard, but it's a very impressive tech demo that gets you to conceptualize something that nobody else has ever tried to show you
 
azetoh

1
Non recommandé
8.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 mars 2022
To me, Hyperbolica feels like a tech demo that tries to be a game, but falls short.

From the devlogs on Youtube, I know a huge amount of pioneering effort went into this game. I personally think the places where this game works best (a maze, a chest-pushing puzzle, a puzzle involving some gophers) are puzzle scenarios where the game has the non-euclidean aspect of the geometry baked into the problem or the solution, and I think that's what a lot of people, hearing about this game, watching the devlogs explaining all the (many!) interesting side-effects that were unique to non-euclidean spaces, were hoping for.

Unfortunately, a lot of this game's content could be done perfectly well (if not better) in euclidean geometry, and seems to have simply been adapted to non-euclidean geometries because it can be, which leaves a somewhat directionless and bland end result. The blandness continues in the NPCs, of which most just give flavour text as dialogue (only a small number are actually relevant to the plot, few have much personality) and the story, which mostly amounts to a giant multi-step fetch quest.

What this means is that the asking price (£13.49 at the time of writing) is being charged for a (admittedly technologically impressive) rendering engine, a very small number of interesting puzzles, and a bunch of filler content. (The game can be beaten in a couple hours, this should paint a picture of how much actual gameplay is being paid for here.)

I unfortunately find it hard to believe that is worth it, so I sadly cannot recommend this game to others.
 
eJ121
4
37 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
3
Recommandé
9.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 mars 2022
Feels more like a tech demo than a true "game," but I'm fine with that. Given that the game is the first of it's kind, it may be easy to be underwhelmed if you expect the game beyond the geometry aspect to be revolutionary.

The overall gameplay is very very simple; run around in one of the six areas looking for people to talk to and things to pick up with a minigame or two in each. The story is hardly existent and the replayability isn't all that much. Furthermore, certain things like the squeegee minigame cannot be replayed (as far as I know) without creating a new game, which was one of the few ways in the game to experience how height affects your vision. The VR (on day 1 at least) was kinda buggy with controls and having to look where to aim in snowball fights and ski minigame felt less than intuitive too.

A lot of people complain about high NPC count and dialogue, but I don't mind it that much. Sure some of the jokes fall flat on their face or can be awkward, but there's a lot of cleverness here and there. Things like the "De Sitter Farms" or "NIL" as the name of the antagonistic entity (only true math fans will get that one) are some that come to mind. Even small things like the angle of the corners of the dialogue boxes being different in elliptic vs hyperbolic shows the amount of charm the game can have. The hub world is larger than it seems (by design) which I like, since instead of all the interesting stuff being concentrated in the center, it's actually at the edges where there's more space for that stuff. So with the world being so large despite seeming so small I strongly feel that with any less NPCs, the game would feel MUCH more empty.

Despite lackluster gameplay and replayability, it's still a very fascinating and unique experience. There is currently no other way to explore these interesting geometries in such a polished and visually appealing way. Most of the fun for me came from having to literally relearn all the fundamentals of spatial awareness that I've had my entire life. Even in such a "low-content" game, I can guarantee that in the span of a few hours, nobody has a GOOD intuition about the world; I'm very comfortable with navigating all the areas and even the maze, but it still catches me off guard taking four 90 degree turns in the same direction in the maze and being somewhere completely different from where i started even though I cognitively know that's how it works.

Another example of having to rewire your brain would be the skiing minigame. In most other games, skiing through a forest trying not to hit anything would be trivially easy. In hyperbolic space however, things far away come at you fast, and it's easy to panic thinking you're running out of space equally fast when in reality it's closer to the opposite. Every time I would take a corner, I had to remind myself that on the exits, I have MUCH more room to play with than I would intuitively think and no corner is super tight. As a result, none of the skill-based games and achievements are particularly hard at their core, but coupled with the unintuitive environment, these simple tasks have serious learning curves.

As a result, I feel as if this game should have leaned less in the direction of slow paced npc/questing or "puzzles" which don't take full advantage of the game's one defining trait and more in the direction of sandbox, obstacle course, or movement based gameplay where the the new environments excel (although admittedly, the controls can feel clunky and unresponsive sometimes). A movement based game like racing or obstacle course game may have forced you to gain an intuition for the enviornment much more than this, and a sandbox game may have let you more freely explore how things interact and behave in this new environment. Ultimately though, there was no real way for CodeParade or anyone else to know what type of game fits this new environment best until it's made, bearing in mind that the engine needed to be made from scratch.
As a whole, the game is best described as "fine;" gimmicky with nothing particularly special, but very far from unenjoyable or unplayable with some charm and serious learning curves here and there. In my opinion, the new geometries weren't taken advantage of fully in this game, but hopefully now that the engine has been made (and logged quite well on YouTube) and it has been proven that interactive worlds CAN be made in this geometry, the flood gates have opened *and others should experiment and expand upon this.

*This is left as an exercise to the reader.
 
Filthy Mickey

Évaluation publiée le 14 mars 2022
Hyperbolica takes place in trippy non-euclidian worlds.

I have followed the development since the beginning of the devlogs and bought it as soon as I got the notification it was released. Since I just bought it, I have not played much, but what I have experience I am really enjoying.

The non-euclidian worlds work really well and are very interesting to explore. They can be a bit disorienting so make good use of the map. If you get motion sick or dizzy easily I would recommend taking breaks if you start to feel sick but I suggest you try the game out.

I am really looking forward to trying it in VR (I'll probably vomit, not looking forward to that part). Yes it does support VR. I'm really stoked that VR is included as that is a very exciting experience. Being able to explore non-euclidian geometry with my own eyes is something I have never experienced and this seems like an excellent way to experience it.

Évaluation publiée le 30 décembre 2022
Having seen an early demo, was excited to check this out—love the crazy geometry/perspective. And that aspect of the game did turn out to be pretty cool! I especially loved wandering through the spherical farm and the infinite restaurant environments.

But, the "game" aspect of it is incredibly dull, tedious, and uninspired. I couldn't follow or find myself caring about the forced storyline, and it was all just endless dialogue windows, mini-games with frustrating and unpleasant movement mechanics, walking from point a to point b and back again over and over—I kept wishing each task was over as soon as it started.

So much potential here, hope something better can come out of the really novel non-euclidean geometry/perspective.

0
Non recommandé
5.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 avril 2022
I despise having to give this game a negative review but as it stands I just cannot give it a thumbs up in good faith. I've been following the devlogs on YouTube for many months. Creating a game in hyperbolic space is a stunning achievement and the dev has my highest respect for that. Unfortunately, Hyperbolica lacks in virtually all other aspects. It's a mediocre game built on top of a stellar foundation.

In most areas of the game, hyperbolic space boils down to "it's confusing". Some elements highlight properties of hyperbolic space but not in a way that would actually impact the gameplay. There is for instance (minor spoiler ahead) a fence that goes in a straight line and an NPC telling you that in hyperbolic space you have to keep turning to keep walking next to it. But that's literally it, the fence's straightness has no meaning in the gameplay. In general, most interactions are trivial, the tasks feel random and pointless. The game also tries to be funny, but just isn't.

What I think should have been done instead is to dedicate to each area one key property of hyperbolic space and guide the player while they are exploring the property. This would allow the player to become more and more skilled in navigating hyperbolic space and because of this learning curve it would also allow more advanced puzzles in later areas.

Speaking of puzzles – Hyperbolica should be a puzzle game! I don't see how a puzzle-free game can make use of hyperbolic space other than "oh it's a bit confusing around here, don't get lost".
 
prestoaghitato
1
75 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Non recommandé
3.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 mars 2022
It's smaller on the inside.

After waiting for the game for 1.5 years, Hyperbolica ended up being a mixed bag. The non-euclidean environments are mind-bending (in a good way) and a bit nauseating (in a bad way). I was kind of expecting a puzzle game, but in the 3.5 hours it took me to finish the game there were maybe 2 or 3 puzzles. I can accept that Hyperbolica is not focused on puzzles, but in my mind it does not succeed as an exploration or comedy game either. I'm glad I got to experience the game's environments and I think the world needs more innovative games like this, but ultimately only the end result matters.

The writing is, for the lack of a better word, cringy. There are way too many NPCs, usually with nothing interesting or funny to say. Their lines remind me of Pokemon NPCs mixed with Reddit comments. Thinly veiled pop culture references are not comedy nor clever observations. There is technically a story but it doesn't really go anywhere or affect anything.

The exploration aspect is mostly walking around the world & pressing E on everything to receive items, then backtracking to a different environment to rub them on something to receive more items. I did not 100% the game so there might be more interesting things to find but what I saw during my playthrough did not motivate me to continue. Some of the game's environments are excellent, but equally many are repetitive and boring (such as the winter world and most of the city).

The game world is far too large for the amount of actual content there is, which is made worse by the most interesting aspect of the game: the use of hyperbolic geometry. Since spaces have much more volume than they would in a traditional euclidean game, there is simply more area to fill with things to do. Hyperbolica has chosen to populate every space with the aforementioned NPCs because they are relatively cheap and quick to produce. I understand the time and budget constraints of indie development, but maybe they should have kept the world smaller and focused on quality over quantity.

Also, screw the skiing minigame. I spent at least half an hour trying to complete it until I figured out a sufficiently cheesy strategy to maximize fuel use.
 
simssi
813 produits enregistrés
0
179 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
8
Non recommandé
2.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 mars 2022
The program is cool. As a math nerd I have really enjoyed eploring the hyperbolic space in an interactive environment and trying to get some new intuitions about how such a world would work. It just isn't a good game.

The main storyline lacks reason: you just keep doing things that a blue robot told you (it's meaninglessness is canonical and it doesn't make it better), and the ending pops out of nowhere. The only interesting story in the game was the ice world questline, and it was still short and shallow.

Most quests required finding stuff and talking to specific people, which is extremely tedious to do in such a large world filled with NPCs without any quest markers. After the farm quest I spent five minutes checking NPCs in search for the one that will give me the quest reward. Barely any quest required thinking and my only "Aha!" moment in this game was finding the artist in the art gallery. As a puzzle game Hyperbolica is boring and repetitive.

Some quests checked your "skill" in playing 3D FPP games, like the drone race or the infinite caffe. Those also didn't bring much enjoyment as the game's controlls are not responsive enough to be an action game, and the caffe part was especially frustrating: controlling the skates was almost impossible and bumping into anything is a 10 second loss. This game's physics and controlls aren suited for action gameplay and the parts that demand it should be much easier.

The most frustrating parts of the game were those requiring aiming, namely the cafe and the snowball fight. Even in a familiar environment and without the janky gravity it would be hard to consistently hit anything without the crosshair and with projectiles being thrown at a weird angle. The 3:1 disadvantage in the snowball fight meant that the only viable strategy was to back out of range of the kids and spam in their general direction until they lost. This section also deserves a solid nerf.

The last thing I want to complain about is the final boss. As I already said, this game's physics and controls aren't suited for action gameplay. The rest of the game suffers from an unintuitively large hitbox and floaty controls, but it all gets exponentially worse when you are supposed to dodge bullets coming from all directions and you can't even strafe up and down! Fortunately the HP system is very forgiving and I managed it on my first try. It is't very interresting story-wise either. The evil AI disappears from your mind as fast as it was introduced.

It's a cool indie game, not very good but also not very bad. It's based on an interesting idea that wasn't expanded with enough creative and well-built content, and it's just not worth the money.

EDIT: Some comment's I'd like to respond to:

1. If you talk to NPCs the ending is forshadowed
I saw some of this forshadowing, but talking to all NPCs is just extreemely unrewarding. Most of them have a few uninteractive lines that don't add to the game's experience so at some point I just stopped talking to every single person I saw.

2. The game's alright for 15$
For you working folks in USA maybe it's alright, but I'm a college student in Poland, and I when I spend 70 PLN on a game I expect it to last at least a week, not two hours.

3. CodeParade made the engine all by themselves
I know and I appreciate it. Just after playing the game I don't feel that the experience was worth the money for me. I didn't buy a game engine, I bought a game and I'm judging it as a game.
 
AlexMM
134 produits enregistrés

51 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
2
Non recommandé
0.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 juin 2022
I saw some of the making of the game and then shut myself away from it. And that was my mistake. On paper and in prototype this is amazing. Creating and interacting with worlds quite literally impossible. Not thanks to a story and art direction, but the mechanics of perspective and distorting what's possible. At this time it is unique in mechanics; to a degree that no other game has come close to.

Except it's not just that. I really wish it was.

On top of everything I glowed about there is now a game. Makes sense; gotta make something for people to do with these impossible mechanics. Except the games you'd suspect; shooter, action, exploration, puzzle... it's a walking sim. Yes you go on little side quests where the mechanics change; jump high or faster movement. Most of the game I played was walking to generic NPCs claiming to be amazed by a VR world. They were having a better time than I was. I thought the boot up on a classroom was going to be a set up for the game to then open up and defy expectation. When it was more of the same I was so deflated.

My core issue isn't the game; it functions. It's that you have Superliminal who has a single mechanic and goes hard with presentation. Antichamber who understands it's mechanics on a base level and fits gameplay to perfectly match them. Then you have Hyperbolica; stalling out the game with NPC chatter. Some of the best mechanics tucked away behind text boxes. I respect what has been created, but it lose me before I saw it.
 
Solid

aktb980

24 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
3
Recommandé
0.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 mars 2022
一个关于非欧世界的精致demo，但游戏性一般

关注这个游戏相当长一段时间了，作者 CodeParade 经常分享一些分形几何、非欧几何的有趣小例子（可以在 itch.io 上找到）
这次的 Hyperbolica 算是一个比较大的工程，也断断续续地在两年内发布了7个 devlog，如果对相关的数学原理、代码实现和图形演示感兴趣的话可以看看他的频道，或者我搜集的这个列表：https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLISPRcNM8VGtOEOoz9f13CPK2pvX9rkpg

通常说到非欧几何（Non-Euclidean geometry），指的是其狭义的定义，也即如何重新定义平面几何第五公设。由此引出的双曲几何与椭圆几何，正是本游戏所展现的核心内容。目前很少有类似这种世界观的游戏，一是游戏引擎限制（CodeParade 在 Unity 里实现这个效果用了很多 hacks），二是可能这种效果更适合作为图形学演示，而不是嵌入到游戏的核心玩法中（我暂时想不出一个现有的游戏类型，可以和非欧几何世界观紧密结合的）

另外还有一些游戏也打上了 Non-Euclidean 的标签，比如 Antichamber、Superliminal、Glitchphobia[www.alphabetagamer.com]、Rooms[www.freegameplanet.com] 等等，但这些游戏更类似于埃舍尔式的视错觉解谜，“空间流转，别有洞天”，严格来讲并不属于非欧几何，甚至也并没有用到新的几何学。但是从游戏性来讲，这类游戏可能更能给人持久的新鲜感。

购买建议
如果不是对非欧几何这个特定话题感兴趣，不建议购买。游戏玩法以探索为主，主要内容是到处闲逛，收获不一样的视角（以及挥之不去的眩晕感），并没有很多解密或者刺激肾上腺素的环节。VR没有尝试，不知道眩晕能力会不会更进一步（

GNU/Linux Support: Native
OS
Fedora Workstation 35
Kernel
5.16.12-200.fc35.x86_64
CPU
AMD Ryzen 7 PRO 5850U with Radeon Graphics (16) @ 1.900GHz
GPU
AMD ATI 07:00.0 Cezanne
 
Mono
146 produits enregistrés
1
22 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
3
Recommandé
7.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 mars 2022
感谢其乐鉴赏家活动提供的游戏副本 欢迎阅读发布在其乐Keylol论坛[keylol.com]上的配图文章以获得最佳体验 “我的神经网络深邃，我乃机中精锐； 你那可怜的小脑瓜甚至不图灵完备！“

《Hyperbolica》是一部我个人虽然无比喜爱、却又感到有些可惜的作品。作为理科科普爱好者兼油管主CodeParade最疯狂、最富有雄心的项目，它对“双曲几何”这一核心创意的演绎独特而富有趣味；但要享受这一切，却需要建立在你原本就对双曲几何有一定理解的基础上。换句话说，《Hyperbolica》与其说是一款游戏，某种意义上更像是CP先生一系列科普视频的附赠品。

而我在惋惜之余最大的想法，则是回到半个月前、给自己一个大嘴巴子：谁让你在QQ里到处说“《Hyperbolica》是三月唯一霸权”，又信心满满地跑去论坛申请写鉴赏的？这下自己不仅要认真评鉴整个游戏，还得圆回自己吹出的牛，同并不熟悉双曲几何的朋友们说明白游戏的精彩之处。

让我们开始吧，唉。

虚拟现实人会梦见几何异世界吗？
连年的疫情，令居家学习与办公成为了越来越多人的选择；《Hyperbolica》的故事便从作为学生的主角戴上VR设备、进入虚拟现实提供方“BrainLink”的环境中，参与一场线上教学开始。
正站在虚拟教室中的虚拟讲台上虚拟授课的，是常在各种青春史诗故事中客串大反派的存在：戴眼镜的数学女教师。这一套“讲课加布置作业”的组合拳，主角哪能够轻易接下，短短数分钟后他便已经精神涣散、昏昏欲睡。

好吧，生动描绘故事并非我的强项，后面发生的事情就让我长话短说：主角醒来后发现自己连带着课桌穿越到了一片陌生的草地上，而身边恰好有一个路标和一名友善的陌生人，我们暂且称他小蓝。小蓝告诉主角，你通过打瞌睡进入了这片BrainLink中的神秘区域：“双曲界”（Hyperbolica），一个与现实世界截然不同的双曲空间。来都来了，那就请您遵循古老的预言，寻找散落在双曲界中的五枚“柏拉图晶体”（五种正多面体），为这个世界带来秩序与平衡吧！

……暂且先不管一切为何这么凑巧、VR空间里又怎么会有啥“古老的预言”，整个游戏的目标非常清晰：进入分散在大地图外侧的五个区域地图，完成地图中的五个任务，获得五枚晶体并通关游戏。作为一款流程并不复杂的半开放式冒险游戏，《Hyperbolica》的大引导做得还是很不错的。五个区域地图的色调、结构都有着分明的特点，实在没有方向时还可以找到大地图中的预言家，向他寻求提示。

一些差评中提到，游戏的全流程不过两小时，这一点我认为有必要澄清：两小时是只进行主线任务所需的时长，而《Hyperbolica》设计了许多乐趣不亚于主线的支线任务与隐藏物品，而独立完成全物品收集、解锁隐藏结局则需要约五到六小时的游戏时间。全收集的难度不大、流程富有趣味，以此作为本作游玩时长的标准更加合理。

游戏世界中有大量NPC、上百条可以触发的对话，而这些台词对游戏体验的影响因人而异。设定中，虚拟空间中的其他角色都是从现实中连接进入的活人（其实不是），于是游戏中的台词常带来一种略显混乱的“超游”感：有的人在双曲界里玩“角色扮演”、入戏到有点幼稚，有的人又直接跳出了双曲界中的叙事、谈论自己的现实生活与感受；在并不出彩的写作水平“加持”之下，游戏文本的整体代入感不太理想。好在，游戏作者在文本中埋下了大量数学相关的梗与冷笑话，假如你是一名对3B1B、Veritasium乃至CodeParade本人等的科普作品感兴趣的数学爱好者，那么在这些对话中寻获“彩蛋”，倒也是一件乐事。

但是，“双曲界”究竟是个啥？
在其他以非常规空间为卖点的游戏，例如《Superliminal》或者《Manifold Garden》中，游戏空间大体还是符合常规认知的，而违背常识的“bug区域”足够集中、明显，玩家能够轻松地注意到异样，并快速总结出新的规律。
《Hyperbolica》却完全不同：整个游戏空间都以一种微妙的方式违反常识，可游戏中却没有任何一位NPC愿意和玩家说清楚，这个“双曲界”具体有什么独特的规律；哪怕是充当向导角色的小蓝也只是在开头轻描淡写地提了一句“你看到的是幻觉，实际情况完全相反”。到底是怎么相反了？先前对双曲几何并不了解的玩家，恐怕很快就会放弃思考这个问题。

一个以科普为初衷的游戏，最后反而要求玩家主动去“对上电波”，多少有些过分。我本想试着越俎代庖一番、系统科普一遍双曲几何的知识，但只凭文字进行介绍，多少需要耗费一番口舌；为了不破坏阅读体验，这部分内容就放在了本篇评测的末尾。
简单总结一下，双曲空间相较于现实有两点特性：其一，双曲空间中的“直线”事实上呈弧形，一对“相互平行”的直线会随着延长不断岔开，视觉上的透视效果更夸张；其二，当你在双曲空间中移动时，会感到世界正围绕着自己旋转。

利用双曲几何的特性制作游戏早先也曾有人尝试，其中最为成功的作品当属《HyperRogue》。这款回合制策略游戏对传统的正六边形格子棋盘施以改变，用六-七边形混合格子密铺了一块无限大的双曲面，打破了常规棋盘中固定的直线线路与格子权值，引导玩家在千变万化的场景中寻找动态的规律、做出更加有趣的决策。Edwin老师的评测中有对《HyperRogue》更详细的介绍，在此也感谢他为本篇评测给予的帮助。

回到《Hyperbolica》的世界：在一个哪怕开着小地图也很难找准方向的三维双曲空间中设计地图与关卡，该如何有效引导玩家的注意力，又该如何让玩家逐渐熟悉整个环境呢？
基于这个标准，整个游戏的关卡设计带给我的感受，应当说是参差不齐的。孰优孰劣，游戏中的五张区域地图中各有显著体现，不妨浅谈一番。

美术馆
全称为“非欧几里得神秘展览馆”（Non-Euclidean Museum Obscura）的NEMO美术馆，是我个人认为兼具欣赏价值与游戏体验、整个游戏中最为精髓的一张地图——说这张地图值回了五十多元的游戏票价，也毫不夸张。
在开阔的双曲面上，安置着数十余件形态各异的“展品”，它们在富有艺术气息的同时融入了数学的奥妙：你可以轻松辨识出克莱因瓶、谢尔宾斯基三角等大名鼎鼎的造型，也或许会发现一些不太为人所知的彩蛋。而它们同时也是一系列值得关注的目标，清晰连接起了玩家的行动路径，还能在玩家重复探索的过程中带来一些惊喜（由于双曲空间的特性，第一次探索时总会有被忽略的方向）。
美术馆中获取水晶的主线任务也颇有意思：一座“牙刷与牙齿”展品的外形明示玩家跳上牙刷，在此之后玩家会发现，数个展品的顶部竟连接成了一组跳跃平台。在跳跳乐的同时，玩家也可以从更高的角度欣赏这些展品，观察它们的形状如何在双曲空间中产生了扭曲。

咖啡厅
在双曲界城镇区域的入口显眼处，营业着一家名为“无限咖啡厅”的小店。如此命名并非是因为咖啡厅内部有着无限大的空间，而是由于咖啡厅中没有“墙角”，一对相邻的墙面并非直接相交，而是在无穷远处重合。
咖啡厅地图的整体结构类似于维切克分形——一个自我嵌套的十字形状，自相似的结构配合地图中不同方位的地板染色，使得玩家理解和记忆起来并不困难。这张地图中的主线任务需要玩家穿梭于咖啡厅中，在规定时间内完成十次指定座位的送餐。两点之间自然是直线最短最省时，但双曲空间中的“直线”还是直的吗？这个小游戏便旨在鼓励玩家思考这一问题。

雪地&迷宫
同上述两张引导清晰、探索富有趣味的地图相比，雪地的设计有些令我摸不着头脑：在白茫茫的原野与被积雪覆盖的树木之间，能够作为参照物的只有一条横跨地图中央的栅栏，稍微往外走几步就会失去方向。在这张地图中，两批用户正因为吃早餐时先放谷物还是先放牛奶而划分阵营、展开一场冷战。《格列佛游记》的故事的确深入人心，但一群现代的成年人怎么可能为了这种小事而浪费现实中的精力呢？

雪地图虽然引导和主线任务一般，但好歹还有打雪仗和滑雪两个值得玩玩的小游戏；而迷宫图的游戏体验，则是纯粹的灾难了。我能理解这张地图的主要目的是玩弄玩家的方向感，毕竟在双曲空间中，“先向前后向右”与“先向右后向前”会让玩家到达不一样的方位；但在一个第一人称、视角被一堵堵围墙截断的迷宫中，大多数玩家压根不会去尝试寻找方向，而是会凭直觉随意走动。若是真的有玩家想描绘出地图的全貌，在他拿起纸笔后就会发现，这个在双曲面上设计的迷宫压根无法等比例绘制到平面上。假如迷宫中没有随时回到入口的功能、没有那一个直接给玩家标明终点方向的NPC，这张烂图恐会劝退更多的玩家。

农庄
与游戏中的其他区域完全不同，农庄的地图结构为球形空间而非双曲空间。这里有着完全相反的规律：“直线”会收敛并最终闭合，远处的物体看起来反而比近处的要大。
或许是因为球形空间的“异常”之处更加直观，农庄的结构反倒比其他几张双曲空间的地图要更好理解。当初次从谷仓走出时，玩家会惊讶地观察到农庄中“近小远大”的奇观；地图上还有连接地面上两个端点的隧道一条与跳板一组，可以让玩家亲自在其间穿梭，理解球形空间闭合的性质。

总结
《Hyperbolica》果真像很多差评中所说的“空有噱头”吗？我是不同意的。这款游戏真正的问题在于富有想法却不够成熟：作者尽管在开发过程中克服了大量的代码与设计困难，最后却没能将自己的灵感转化为深入浅出的游戏体验。
它或许是一款“中看不中用”的矛盾之作，但仅凭它对三维双曲空间的准确展现与刻画，我依然愿意推荐这部作品。如果你有兴趣探索双曲几何的奥妙、有耐心融入《Hyperbolica》的节奏当中，它带给你的将是一段奇异而绝伦的体验。


附录：双曲几何简介

若要谈论以双曲几何与球面几何为主的非欧几何，就得从经典的欧氏平面几何说起。约公元前300年，古希腊数学家欧几里得撰下巨著《几何原本》，将零散的几何知识重构成了一座逻辑严密、初具规模的平面几何大厦。
在《几何原本》中，欧几里得首先指明了23个定义来描述原始的几何概念、5条公理与5条公设来框定平面几何的基本规则，而后在它们的基础上进行逻辑推导，证明了大量富有价值的命题。《几何原本》的命题与推导方式，极大地启发了后世的数学研究工作，也在两千余年后成为了我们中学课本上的一个个知识点。

《几何原本》中的5条公设具体如下：
1.过两点能作且只能作一直线
2.线段可以无限地延长
3.以任一点为圆心,任意长为半径,可作一圆
4.凡是直角都相等
5.同平面内一条直线和另外两条直线相交，若在直线同侧的两个内角之和小于180°，则这两条直线经无限延长后在这一侧一定相交

与前四条“优雅”的公设相比，第五公设（也称平行公设）显得格外臃肿。它真的是这座平面几何大厦下一块不可或缺的基石吗？在欧几里得之后，有许多数学家抱着上述的怀疑，尝试通过前四条公设推导出第五公设，而这一试就是上千年。

19世纪初，俄国数学家罗巴切夫斯基在《几何学原理及平行线定理严格证明的摘要》中，首次公开提出了对第五公设的新理解。他在论文中指出，如果改变第五公设（例如，内角和小于180°的两条直线也可能不相交），将会得到一个与欧氏几何大有差异、却仍然自洽的几何体系。很可惜，这一“新几何”直到他离世后才逐渐被世人所理解和承认，而为了纪念他的贡献，他所构建的双曲几何体系也被称为“罗氏几何”（Lobachevskian geometry）。

双曲几何与欧氏平面几何有着许多共通之处，但你很快就会发现，带着来自平面几何的“直觉”进入双曲几何的世界，将会寸步难行：比如，双曲空间中该如何定义“直线”呢？画一条看上去笔直的线，换个视角看就又变成了曲线。
在许多双曲几何研究（以及《Hyperbolica》）中，直线采用的是庞加莱模型中的定义：以空间内给定一点为圆心作单位圆（庞加莱圆盘），所有过圆心且与单位圆垂直相交的圆弧，均为过该点的直线。此种广义上的“直线”有一个更加常用的名称：测地线。

双曲几何中的测地线是发散的。这便意味着，一对共面且垂直于同一条直线的“平行线”，会在双曲空间中随着直线的延长不断拉开距离、形成喇叭状的轮廓，而非同欧氏几何中那样有着固定的间距。这一规律表现在游戏中，便导致了相比于现实更加夸张的透视效果：如果一束射入眼中的“平行光”来自越远的地方，它们的初始间距也就越大，因此相同范围的视野中会容纳更多的画面。

许多教材与教学视频会以“马鞍面”的形式描绘双曲面，而这给很多人带来了一个误会，即双曲面是一个被从某处捏紧、两头收缩两头发散的形状。事实上，双曲面与双曲空间均朝着所有方向发散，这导致了他们的正确形状无法被直观、完整地表现出来。《Hyperbolica》中主要采用球极平面投影绘制双曲空间，因此游戏世界看起来类似于一个球面；在通关后的制作名单界面中，游戏也展示了其它几种投影方式的效果。

（有必要补充一点：游戏的介绍中提到“双曲空间中不存在平行线”，但这是错误的：平行线的定义是一对共面且不相交或重合的直线，而在双曲几何中，过一点可以作无数条与已知测地线平行的测地线。同样，前一段中提到的“平行线”“平行光”也不和真正的平行线定义等价。）

双曲几何的性质还有着其他表现，例如双曲面上的四边形的内角和小于360°（具体大小由曲率决定），四个“矩形格子”无法拼成一个完整的大矩形。这造成了一件非常有趣的事情：在双曲面上向前走一格并向右走一格，会到达与向右走一格并向前走一格不同的位置；而在上面绕行“一圈”后，也不会回到最开始的位置与朝向。换言之，移动时的交换律被破坏了。因此，当你在双曲面上漫步时，会感觉到周遭的世界正在缓慢“旋转”，原先选定的参考点也似乎慢慢地移动了位置。

Recommandé
9.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 avril 2023
Welp... As an actuall game experience this game sort of kind of sucks butt. If you expect a puzzle experience then no this game is mostly not it. Errand quests, sprinkle of some mini-games here and there (EXTREMELY HARDCORE minigames btw, that ski one requires some ace piloting skills), alsoyou've got lots of NPCs that are cute but at the same time just spill bollocks at you.

Why positive review then? BECAUSE it's a frikkin hyperbolic space and it looks awesome! And is done pretty convincing and seamless too. And also there is a spheric space that is just nuts. So all and all even if this game is just an interactive non-euclidian museum, it was bananas to me because it's a fresh experience.

Also I've subscribed to CodeParade on Youtube and love his videos so that probably also contributed to a good review (his videos are a great geek food).

So buy if you're into that. Don't expect it to be a Portal or Superliminal tho, for that there are other games.

18 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 mars 2022
TL:DR, I do not regret paying full price, and thoroughly enjoyed my experience, but its realistically a tech demo showing the aspects of various non-euclidean geometries rather than a fleshed out game.

The idea is fantastic, and being able to play around with, and be in non-euclidean geometries is quite the experience.

However... I only recommend the game for the experience of being in, and playing around with non-euclidean geometries, otherwise, and I hate to say it given I followed the devlogs and followed the hypetrain, its not a good 'game' as such.

The end was fantastic however, and showed the potential puzzle, combat, and movement capabilities of such a type of game. Imagine an arena style game with spherical pocket dimensions and hyperbolic dimensions. Or a portal style puzzle game that takes advantage of the way angles work in a hyperbolic world such as on such puzzle in this game.

However for this game, its a tech demo. A fantastic experience of a tech demo, don't get me wrong, but none-the-less, a tech demo.
 
Sonny0jim
123 produits enregistrés
0
54 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
2
Non recommandé
3.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 avril 2022
I was really hyped by Hyperbolica very early in its development, from the author's youtube channel.
So when it came out, I just instantly bought it.

Well, I must say I was disappointed...
3.6 hours, Steam tells me, and I finished it with zero compulsion to come back to it. Its €14 seem quite a lot for that time, especially considering the experience offered.

The main idea of the game, its "selling point", is meant to be about its mind blowing geometry. And what we were shown in the early youtube videos truly was promising.
The 5 perpendicularly connected rooms example was really effective in the close setup of the video. The outside equivalent in the game is a lot less confusing.
The short tunnel that leads to a far away place, or the one that goes up while leading to a place that is actually lower. I could see none of those strange things in the game.

The game design and gameplay aren't on a sufficient level either, and the story kind of suddenly come out of nowhere, in some sort of awkward justification for the endgame boss fight... A boss fight which, in my opinion, was globally uncomprehensible and unmanageable.
Overall the general gameplay basically revolves around a series of fetch quests and 2 or 3 minigames where most of the challenge comes more from the rough controls than from the confusing geometry (which isn't that much confusing, really)

I do not like expressing such a hard opinion on this game but... there it is.

The thing is : the initial concept and the engine developed to showcase it is really good... but as a showcasing demo. As a game, it still lacks a lot.
 
Catox
0
20 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1
Recommandé
2.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 mars 2022
Learned about non-euclidean graphics in college and now I can finally experience it visually. I have a headache from playing but it's worth it. Some people here are complaining about not enough story line or other game elements, but you have to realize this is one of the first games that uses this type of graphics system.

I hope that CodeParade will put his non-euclidean engine to use and work with other game developers to build a bigger sequel (with more gameplay and story), but I have to say for a one-man project this game was insane and I had a great time playing.

Évaluation publiée le 19 juin 2022
Prior to playing Hyperbolica, I had been watching the dev-log videos and keeping up to data with the game's development. Learning about non-euclidean geometry has been an interest of mine and playing this game was a fantastic way to see how living in these geometries would look and feel. Throughout the game I had to rewire my internal guidance, trying to get an intuition of the areas. After while I was able to, generally, get around well.

The story of the game was not that exciting, but it didn't need to be since it wasn't the star of the show. My main criticism of the game is that there should be a sprint button. Running back and forth to fully 100% of the game took longer because of that, but was still manageable.

Overall, if you are interested in experiencing non-euclidean geometry, then I would recommend this game!

Évaluation publiée le 14 mai 2022
Bought this game because i've been following the developer for a few years now, the things he showed in his videos looked amazing, and he's accomplished something very impressive with the rendering tech he's made. But, the actual game design is terrible, there's barely any gameplay, all feels very samey, one of the levels was actually just a half an hour long maze... This has probably got to be the most painfully boring game I've ever played and it could have been so much better if the "story" was dropped and it was a half an hour long game made to show all the cool tech and illusions. I DO NOT want to sit through 20 minutes of mindnumbing dialogue that serves no purpose but to drag the game out. It's really sad because he could have made a very cool experience with the tech but instead made a game intentionally easy to get lost in with more padding that I thought was ever possible, this leaves little to no space to show the cool effects that were SUPPOSED to be the heart of this game from the beginning.

Recommandé
2.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 mars 2022
Game feels more like a tech demo for the engine, which itself is very cool and I think has plenty of potential. However the gameplay itself is a little lacking.
The first few minutes of the game are awesome and you can really get lost just exploring the world and figuring out how to orient yourself in the strange environment you're presented with. However, the game had a lot of potential to have really interesting and engaging physics and geometry focused puzzles, which I was really hoping to get when the game came out. Unfortunately, it feels like it's really missed the mark on incorporating some good puzzles into the game. There was a lot more just clicking through dialog and running around. There are a few cool puzzles, for example the one with the treasure chest I thought was quite cool, but it was kind of hidden away, it was very minor, and it is the exception. There aren't many other puzzles like that one that creatively take advantage of the Non-Euclidean space.

Despite the drawbacks though, it's still a really cool experience, and there's not many other games out there like this one. I have yet to try it on VR, but even on just a computer screen it can be very engaging.

17 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1
Non recommandé
1.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 mars 2022
This is an extremely cool concept:
  • Likely one of the first games truly using 3d hyperbolic space
  • Great music
  • Visual representation of hyperbolic properties

However, i was a bit underwhelmed by the game itself.

Firstly, the game is incredibly short. Only ~2-3 hours of actual content.

Despite being about hyperbolic space, i honestly rarely even noticed the effect. Most of the spaces are so vast and (mostly) empty that it feels almost normal walking around. Also, it never really felt like the hyperbolic aspect was used in a truly creative way, mostly just as a gimmick. I was hoping to explore much larger areas with much more to do, but it ended up being a "key and keyhole" type where you get an item from one NPC, and give it to another. Very few parts of the game feel like they wouldn't work in a game without hyperbolic geometry.

Speaking of NPCs, it is often extremely difficult to tell whether a NPC is story-related, side-item related, or merely filler. Most of the game you have to talk to random NPCs to hope one of them is related in some way. Most NPCs look visually identical, with only main/recurring npcs having any distinct visual aspects. Even your "sidekick" (which is basically introduced randomly at the beginning of the game for no real reason), looks visually identical to most blue-colored npcs. The only identifying aspect is that NPCs from a certain region have a certain common characteristic.

Overall, i'm disappointed in this game. It had so much potential to have much larger worlds, more to do, more taking advantage of the hyperbolic space, but it's basically just like any other game just with a cool world geometry.
 
NovaStorm93

I love that they made a game engine using hyperbolic geometry, but unfortunately there's almost no game here. If they do something else with this game engine, I'll be glad to try it, but for now I have to pass.

30 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Non recommandé
0.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 mars 2022
I really wanted to like this game, I've been following the development since day one, but I can't.

It's an interesting tech demo, but for $20 I have to review it like a real game; And it fails terribly, in every way, at being a good game. CodeParade is great at what they do but I highly suggest in the future that they partner with someone more involved with game design. Conceptually this game is neat, but it is incredibly lacking in execution.

The dialog is too boring and the voices are too grating to have so much of it, the intro is so boring I can't believe it, the controller has inverted aim and seemingly no way to change it(?), the walk speed is way too slow, the map takes up way too much of the screen (and the combined effects of the 3d hyperbolic world through the transparent 2d hyperbolic map makes for a nightmare to look at imo), the world is too big and the character too undirected for how uneventful exploration is.

There is also so little verticality in the world that despite the core concept being about conceptualising higher geometries the game actually feels less dimensional than typical games, almost as if it it was designed in 2d from a birds eye view or something.

The first quest after the boring intro is to walk 10 feet to talk to another npc. The second quest is to slowly walk around a fairly empty and uninteresting world talking to npcs using the awful dialog mechanic looking for some sort of crystal. Where am I?
Why am I here?
Who is this blue guy?
Why am I doing what he says?
Why do I care to collect "platonic crystals"?
Who is the oracle and why is he giving out maps?
How am I 10 minutes into a game and it hasn't even attempted to hook me with anything interesting?

Hopefully the mini games and puzzles are better but at this price and given my current impression I won't be taking the chance.
 
Worst. Aimbot. Ever.

Non recommandé
2.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 juillet 2022
I'll preface this with the fact that I love the ideas behind this game. It had an intriguing premise and was bursting with potential.

I saw the making of and let the hype get to me.
- That was my first mistake. The game ended up being interesting in theory but boring in execution.
I got into it, started walking. Talked to most npc's that I could.
- That was my second mistake. The dialogue is mostly unique, but the talking sounds are just a 15-second loop of someone doing the verbal equivalent of a keysmash in different tones and timbres, and the dialogue is mostly fluff. They start to feel less like an interesting interaction and more of a chore as time goes on. They are 100% there to pad out the playtime of the game.
I kept on walking (and walking, and walking, and walking, and walking...) through each of the areas. I appreciated the art gallery especially. I had this nagging thought in the back of my head that there should be a story, but other than Collect-a-thon: Polyhedra Edition, there was no substance. I assumed that after collecting the crystals, the story would pick up.
- Mistake number three. There's no story. You collect the shapes, fight a weird boss in noneuclidean space, and then it ends. There was no beginning, middle, or end. It just one big act of "walk around and find things." The whole thing could be summed up in less than a paragraph.

This game... is fine. It's not stellar, it's not garbage, but it's on the low end of mediocre. I won't be getting a refund but I have no intention of playing this game ever again. If it goes on sale at some point, highly recommend, but at its current price it's just not worth it.
 
KF2015
161 produits enregistrés

15 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
8.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 mars 2022
I've watched through the devlogs of this game on YouTube and I'm really happy with this game from a technical perspective. It shows off some very fun non-Euclidean spaces, and does its best to show you some of the quirks of said space.

Unfortunately, from a gameplay perspective, the game isn't great. There are dozens of NPCs - some with quests and dialogue necessary to complete the game - but they're indistinguishable (in all but two cases) from the other endless NPCs with only a few lines of mildly funny dialogue. There are collectables, but most of them are exhausting to collect and don't involve doing anything particularly impressive or fun (one of them lies in an unmarked location in a maze). Hyperbolic space makes this game's playable area extremely large, but it feels incredibly empty (or, at best, filled with filler). Also, for a world full of esoteric secrets, deep lore and an overarching mystery, none of it feels hidden, or something you feel accomplished for seeking out. The final segment of the game, while still technically and cinematically cool, involves a boring gameplay loop (literally) and a somewhat anti-climatic reveal of the game's lore. Finally, there's a segment which involves hunting gophers, and the game doesn't make it clear that every hole has a gopher in it, but they hide when you get close or make noise (I assumed the gophers were burrowing and switching holes, not simply ducking and coming back up).

Overall, being in a hyperbolic environment just isn't utilised very much when solving puzzles or doing quests, past the basics of making you feel disoriented.

At the end of the day, this game doesn't utilise its unique twist enough for me to justify recommending it to my friends who aren't obsessed with non-euclidean geometry (especially given the pricetag). As others have said, it feels very much like a tech-demo, without enough 'game' on its bones to justify most players making their way through it.

I still highly recommend the game for people intrigued by the non-euclidean premise, but I'm not sure I recommend for anyone outside that crowd.
 
Jinan Dangor
0
11 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1
Recommandé
3.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 décembre 2022
Truly one of the strangest games I've ever played.

The quality, to be frank, is all over the place. I think the most limiting factor of the game is that the very nature of its artstyle prevents tall structures from existing- the only three environments where the signature aesthetic is reversed (farm, cafe, and final boss) stand out far, far more than the other dozen environments by a landslide. And because of this, most of the environment of most of the environments ends up far, far too samey, in a very bad way.

That said, there is a surprisingly deep story that you're almost guaranteed to miss most of, given the fractal nature of the open world overworld map, and there are a huge number of extremely excellent minigames and puzzles that make the absolute most out of the nature of the game's world.

I recommend fully to fans of Portal and other non-euclidean games who dont mind wading through a little jank to experience real art.

Évaluation publiée le 4 avril 2022
If you're buying this game for a good story and compelling game-play then this game might not be for you. This game gives you an experience that you won't really find anywhere else, one that is well worth the price. I spent multiple hours just wandering around, the game doesn't offer much in terms of replayability but that doesn't stop me from coming back to this game just to jump off a tall ledge. Every part of this game is made to show off different parts of non-euclidean space and I'm sure it will be the inspiration for many more games like it in the future.

Non recommandé
2.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 septembre 2022
Hyperbolica is... a game. It's more of a tech demo though.
I really want to be able to recommend this game, but there's just nothing here. There's a grand total of 2 puzzles that take advantage of the properties of non-Euclidean spaces, one in spherical space and one in hyperbolic space, which were probably the only interesting parts of the game. There's also the maze, but since you get a map it's kinda trivial, and all it amounts too is "woah, you take take 3 left turns and not return where you started!".
The rest of the game is running around and taking to NPCs, just to pad out the playtime. Which could be forgiven if the story was any good, but it's not. The main plot is you running around and collecting things, and then you fight a boss by orbiting him as he fires projectiles into himself while he explains everything. That's it, that's the entire story. There's a true ending, but it's just more collecting and another boss fight that's more or less the same as the regular ending.
If you really want to play around with Hyperbolic space, play HyperRogue, it actually takes advantage of the properties of non-Euclidean space.

Chevis
0
8 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 mars 2022
TL;DR: THIS GAME IS GOOD BUT NOT WORTH FULL PRICE. WAIT UNTIL IT GOES ON SALE

Hyperbolica is a gimmick game. It has one major idea and concept that is weird and not done before - and then runs with it until it gets tired. Think something like Baba Is You, Superliminal, or the upcoming Patrick's Parabox. And if you're buying this for it's gimmick, it is absolutely worth it. No other game does what Hyperbolica does, playing in a hyperbolic landscape, and it uses it's gimmick to the best of it's ability to do some really cool stuff. However, it is quite flawed.

Hyperbolica is 17 dollars, 18 with tax, and man should it not be that. I 100% completed the entire game in a single night, and there's not really much reason to replay it. It's just a cute little world/tech demo for a neat idea, and I think it's not worth 18 dollars in any way. I enjoy "explore-and-adore" type games, however, if your game is based on exploration, you need stuff to explore, and there's not really much of that here. The entire game is just a hub world with 5 tiny areas to play around in surrounding it, varying in length depending on whether or not you talk to everyone or do all the sidequests and stuff. I did all of the sidequests, talked to everyone I could, and beat it insanely quickly either ways, so who knows how long it feels if you're not a completionist. Gameplay-wise, (talk to quirky characters, explore an odd world and collect items with very little fail-states) it feels very similar to Broken Reality, but Broken Reality is 2 dollars cheaper, and has 4x more content with way more replayability. Yes, it doesn't have the hyperbolic gimmick, but I still don't think that's enough to sway it being worth nearly 20 dollars.

There's also the story, which just feels like it was added in because it had to have a story. Not saying it was bad, just clearly a bit tacked on. It felt like a major ripoff of Hypnospace Outlaw and The Witness in ways I can't talk about too indepth without spoiling all three of the games, but if you know the plot to any of them, you'll pick up on it immediately. It was oddly generic for such a creative game.

To be clear, despite how negative I am here, I quite enjoyed my time with it. I just think you should wait until it's on sale, it's worth that time.
 
jockohomosexual
416 produits enregistrés
2
14 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
1
Recommandé
3.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 mars 2022
Experienced on the Meta Quest 2. VR REVIEW.

You can view my review & gameplay here:
Vidéo YouTube™: Hyperbolica VR Review & Gameplay - A Must Experience for VR, A Trippy Non-Euclidean Adventure Game 
Vues : 1,320
I actually didn't read any of the dev logs for this game or watch the YT channel a lot of people mention. I was aware of the math concepts here, but as a lawyer, I obviously have not done any...


This is so far my VR Game of The Year for 2022. It is, in my opinion, a must experience in VR. There's nothing else quite like it (all apologies to HyperRogue which is another good non-Euclidian game with VR support which is also good, but just not as innovative or jaw-dropping). However, I will admit that this VR experience is not perfect, it definitely has several flaws.

The biggest flaw currently is that motion controllers are not supported on the Meta Quest 2 and some other headsets. Also, related to that, the VR implementation is rather basic. A lot of interactions are gaze-based point & click. However, the dev does plan to patch in Touch controller support. In my opinion, I honestly don't think you'll miss much playing this game in VR now with a gamepad. I don't know what the dev will do with Touch controller support, but I doubt it'll substantially change the experience given its current gaze-based point and click game mechanic.

Another flaw is that the gameplay and story are rather simple. While there are some challenging puzzles, for the most part, most of the puzzles are quite easy to solve. Most of the challenge from this experience is actually just getting from point A to point B, even with a map, simply because of the non-Euclidean geometry involved. There's also just a lot of text box reading in this experience with a lot of puns. While some puns did hit, many also missed. There were definitely some story elements I enjoyed, but many were also quite forgettable.

Lastly, while I don't consider it a flaw, this is a rather intense VR experience. If you have ever experienced VR motion sickness or nausea, this game will likely make you experience it again.

Now, this game did not affect me at all and I played almost 4 hours continuously. This game completely blew my mind. I found the experience to be innovative and unique and it completely changed the way I view math. These abstract mathematical concepts are now something tangible. My jaw was on the floor several times during this experience. This is what VR is meant for, to bring these concepts to life in a way that no other medium can. I just want more of this game honestly. I hope DLC comes or a Steam workshop. I would love to explore other geometries.

Hyperbolica is running on the Unity Engine. On my RTX 3080, I was getting a steady 90 fps. With a gamepad, you have full locomotion and snap turning available. Again, the interactions are gaze-based, point and click interactions. I did not experience any serious issues or bugs.

Rate 8/10. Even though it took me less than 4 hours to complete the game, trying to 100% but failing, it was 100% worth the $16.99 USD I paid and I would have paid more honestly. It was that great an experience for me in VR.

If you enjoyed my review, please consider joining my Steam Curator Group. You can join here: https://steamcommunity.com/groups/Oculus_WMR
 
FastLawyer

Pixstatic
137 produits enregistrés

9 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 12 octobre 2023
To me, Hyperbolica has been a mixed experience.

The game itself, from a technical standpoint, is a real masterpiece. I cannot wrap my head around how the developers conceived and then realized such a product. Having experienced some game developing, I can assure you that while learning you'll struggle with recreating physics and geometry as you're used to see them in real life. I can only imagine how experienced you must be to come up with Hyperbolica.

Basically, this is an exploration game set in a world which is, in fact, hyperbolic, meaning that lines cannot be parallel and you'll most likely find that distant places are, in fact, not that distant. A gimmick? Probably, but it's so satisfying to be able to appreciate a world so different to the one you live in, yet so logical. Math, friends. It always works.

However... it's the artistic direction that I had mixed feelings about (aside from the art museum, which was neat!). To me, it felt really basic and lackluster. Don't get me wrong, I honestly see the technical side of things to be the main thing to be hyped about when trying to evaluate Hyperbolica. But, well... Everything felt really, really basic with poor variety and charisma. The characters in the game are recognizable, I'll give them that, but I feel that with a different art style and narration this could've been ten times better.

Because even the plot is, for me, not worth the gameplay. Very predictable and not really thought out... If I had to give an advice to the developers, well, I would say that doing something more similar to Superliminal or The Stanley Parable could've boosted the overall narrative structure. It seems like they wanted to do something similar, but couldn't.

The worlds themselves, though, are really good. Each has an unique thing about them that reflects the way things work in Hyperbolica. For example: have you ever though how labyrinths would work in an hyperbolic setting? Well, as you may have guessed, it surely is a strange experience.

Levels are well structured, too. They invite you to experience the overall environment.

Of course, Hyperbolica is definitely recommended. Just... enjoy how this world works and don't expect some overly deep plot or fleshed out characters.
 
bottolo
864 produits enregistrés
0
9 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
13.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 mars 2022
I have been hoping to play this game for years, and when I finally got to play it, I can say it was worth the wait (and the money). Turning something that could very easily be a demonstration of the engine into a playable game is no small feat considering the limitations of using a non-Euclidean space.

Yes, it is short, and yes, it is a little rough around the edges, but it's a gem.
And that's not a hyperbole!

1.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 mars 2022
It pains me to say this concidering how big of a fan I am of both non-euclidean geometry, but also the creator Code Parade, but I do not recommend this game, and I felt quite underwhelmed by it. The games requires you to complete tasks to procede, but it has a really bad habit of having a character explain what you have to do, but when you talk to them again due to either missing the information or forgetting it, they have some completely different dialogue that doesn't say anything about what you have to do. This has made it so that I had to search up what to do in certain sections, just because the characters won't explain it to me again.

There is also a section where you have to go back and forth to two locations to give some items to people, and there is absolutely no reason why you would need to go back and forth that much, concidering how the path is very simple, so it is just a big waste of time.

The visuals of this game is really cool and unintuitive, but unfortunately that isn't enough to make me enjoy the game, despite how huge of a fan I was of non-euclidean geometry when I first discovered this game when it was in development.

As of right now I am at what I belive to be the end of the game. So I can not say anything about how good or bad the end/endings are.

Recommandé
15.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 novembre 2022
Hyperbolica has a very innovative style of game play, that being the hyperbolic view you see the world through. It is a very cool concept and makes for an enjoyably story-filled game!
It doesn't take long to get used to the hyperbolic effect but even still, through out the game you notice new, mind-blowing ways that it shifts your perspective.

The story is well put together to keep you intrigued, and it does a good job of making the normally repetitive task of talking to all the NPCs interesting, with the NPCs revealling essential information to understanding the backstory. The game also uses the NPCs as pointers for what to do next and how to obtain the trinkets!

Seriously, I would recommend talking to all of the NPCs you can because the reward, in the form of information that brings the story together, is worth it.

Absolutely would recommend!
 
8-BitTyler

7 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 mars 2022
I enjoy this, but it might not be for everyone. Know what you're getting into.
Hyperbolica is a novel experience presented in a game engine. As a game, it's a passable rpg-lite where you wander around, talk to people, and fulfill certain goals/quests. The dialogue is fun, if a bit intense with the references to current internet culture.
What makes this unique is that the world you explore, and the quests you go on, happen in non-euclidean space. Parallel lines are only parallel at one place. Take more than 4 right turns to end up back where you started. This doesn't change anything about the controls or traversal, but it feels _weird_. Not in a bad way, but in a truly mind-bending way. For me, it's also a stomach churning experience; I cap out at 30 minutes of play, and that's not even in VR.
I thought that starting this game would be like playing a puzzle game; once I figured out the trick, I'd be able to master the environment. However, the "trick" is just the fact that space is just wrong. You move around normally, and at first you might be hard pressed to pinpoint just how the hyperbolic space changes things. Your brain (or my brain, at least) is just unable to process this kind of space. It's cool, it's subtle, and it's fascinating. If you're still interested, definitely try it out.
 
Makana

Évaluation publiée le 7 février 2023
In a nutshell, it's a walking simulator with minigames sprinkled in for good measure. Coincindentally, those minigames showcase non-euclidian space really well, which is the main star of the show. Unsurprisingly, given the name of the game. Really goes to showcase space itself as an active part of the game. Haven't tried it in VR (yet), but it certainly reminds me how great euclidian space is for, y'know, daily business.

6 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
4.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 septembre 2022
<This review is based on Hyperbolica's virtual reality support

A friend introduced me to a mathematical construct called the hyperbolic plane a couple of years ago. He had started playing a game called HyperRogue, a challenging game that requires learning how to navigate in hyperbolic space. At some point I said it'd be interesting to view it in VR, and the game actually has a VR mode. Unfortunately it just looks like nonsense to me.



I believe Hyperbolica does a much better job of giving a sense of what it's like to exist in hyperbolic space. The environments are all familiar types of scenery, so the focus is on how it looks and how you move through the space.

The gameplay is mostly talking to a massive number of NPCs with short & fun things to say. There's a backstory and plot to Hyperbolica, which is a virtual world on a secret server for a brain-computer interface device called BrainLink. Gameplay is basic activities and simple puzzles. I was okay that the game was very basic, because the bizarre landscapes and visuals deserve to be the star of the show.

The other day I learned this game was developed mostly by one programmer and an artist. Major respect to the math-wiz programmer for figuring out how to create an "artist's impression" of hyperbolic space in three dimensions using an existing game engine, Unity, that operates with Euclidean geometry. I figured it was achieved through some amount of "trickery" and the game isn't actually hyperbolic from the ground up. The DevBlog series on the CodeParade YouTube channel explains how the game was programmed and design. Fascinating!

The VR support is supposedly beta, but I completed the game in VR without any issues or complaints. It's marvelous that the game can be viewed in stereoscopic 3D despite how outlandish the visuals are. I was extremely disoriented in my first session, but eventually I got used to how the world looks and how I had to move through it.

This is a nice little game, definitely a must-have for VR. SOILD RECOMMEND!
 
Eincrou
792 produits enregistrés

0
Non recommandé
2.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 mars 2022
I'm already waiting for the sequel.

As right now, it's just a hyperbolic geometry... tech demo. No playability whatsoever.

A few unfocused minigames that sometimes have a twist caused by hyperbolic geometry. It's cool to see the world getting curved and shrinking when viewed from above, and navigating non-euclidean maze is somewhat trippy. But otherwise it's just not fun. How long can you fly drones through simple rings or deliver food around the cafe? What's the point?

The problem is, this game has nothing to offer except hyperbolic geometry. Everything else is trivial, boring or downright annoying. Tons of NPCs around spit lines of dialogue, which tried too hard to be funny. It could even potentially be across some sensible and lenghty plot, but now dialogs just feel like drawing random jokes from an old hat.
Yet you need to read it all - there is no quest log or objective indicator at all, so often the only way to progress is to talk to every NPC you can see. Quest givers do not look any different from random bystanders who mumble irrelevant bollocks.

The graphics is just what you see - sure, I get one man has to code all the rendering from scratch, but anyway - it can be hardly an advantage for anyone. The music is suitable and that's about it.

Despite the potential of being hyper-large, Hyperbolica is in fact a tiny game with no direction, limited design ideas and no effort put into user experience. Will give you three hours max, including only 10 minutes of "wow" novelty sensation.

If you find the concept of hyperbolic geometry interesting, try HyperRogue. It's still one-man bag of ideas, but at least these ideas will get you thinking in new ways. Whereas Hyperbolica has nothing to offer but a few moments of novelty.

Non recommandé
1.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 juillet 2022
I love how CodeParade is pushing the envelope on what's possible in computer games and going against what's traditionally done. I loved Marble Marcher and was very excited about Hyperbolica.

That being said Hyperbolica is a great tech demo, but a terrible game. The world is littered with hundreds of basically identical characters, most of whom have nothing interesting to say. Still, talking to them seems to be the way to push the plot forward. The world is mostly empty and boring, if not for the non-euclidian effects. I played the game for over an hour and managed to find one piece of what you could consider gameplay, which consisted of pushing a chest around the beach.

I know CodeParade is an indie developer, so I wouldn't mind it if the game was short or not polished. From the screenshots I know there's gameplay in it, but I really can't force myself to sift through the non-content to find it.

I really hope the game goes through some playtesting and gets updated/re-released in a more fun incarnation.

Still, I don't regret buying the game and you should consider buying it too. We need more out-of-the-box tech ideas like this one!

Non recommandé
7.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 12 aout 2022
While the idea of a true Non-euclidean game ( not stuff like portals and perspective tricks ) is very cool and the Hyperbolica Engine will probably be used in many innovative games. I also watched the devlogs CodeParade made. However, that will not stop me from pointing out the large problem that many reviews ( mainly negative ) talk about:

𝙏𝙝𝙚 𝙛𝙖𝙘𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧𝙚 𝙞𝙨𝙣'𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙢𝙪𝙘𝙝 𝙜𝙖𝙢𝙚 𝙞𝙣 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙨 𝙜𝙖𝙢𝙚. I'd personally say that it's more of a showcase of Hyperbolic and Spherical geometry than an actual game. Plus many of the characters have no purpose to the ( basically nonexistant ) story and only appear once to comment about something.

Despite all of these, if you wanna play this game, i recommend to do that in VR first ( because that's what i did ) because when i played it normally, it just felt shallow. Something peculiar about VR mode is that in the hyperbolic part of the nil bossfight the game lagged like crazy, may have just been something on the hardware end but it is something of note.

If there was an option for a "kinda" recommendation i would choose that, because while it's engine can ( and probably will ) be used for many innovative games ( like i said earlier ), the game on itself isn't really a game. So in the meanwhile, i'll have to go with a No.

Évaluation publiée le 16 mars 2022
i was so excited for this game, i had watched all the devlogs from the start, and i really really wanted to like it.

unfortunately, i got bored very quickly, either i'm used to being constantly stimulated or the game just doesn't have much of a "game" aspect to it, but it couldn't hold my attention once i was done marveling at the fancy geometry... going around and talking to NPC's is fun until it gets tiring, and it got tiring fast when i got lost and confused, not knowing where to go or what to do beside walking around.

maybe this game just isn't for me, and other people will enjoy it, but i just can't say that it works as a game right now outside of showing off the rendering engine

40 Watt
0
5 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1
Recommandé
7.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 mars 2022
Hyperbolica ist ein surreales und lustiges Spiel, dass in einer Welt mit nicht euklidischer Geometrie spielt.
Die unmögliche Architektur erzeugt dabei eine einzigartige Atmosphäre, die man so einfach noch nicht gesehen hat!

Die Welt
Lasset die Verwirrung beginnen:
In Hyperbolica ist der Raum selbst gekrümmt: Dadurch gibt es keine parallelen Linien, und Fünfecke haben rechte Winkel.
Diese Raumeigenschaften werden durch verschiedene Puzzles und interessante Architektur zur Geltung gebracht:
Zum Beispiel gibt es ein Café, dass trotz rechteckiger Räume keine einzige ecke hat, da diese mathematisch quasi bei unendlich liegen.
Ein anderes Beispiel ist das Labyrinth in dem man nach 4 Linksabbiebungen immer noch nicht im kreis gelaufen ist, sondern in einer komplett anderen Gegend landet.
Die bunten und einfallsreichen Level und Gebiete beleuchten jeweils unterschiedliche Aspekte des Lebens im gekrümmten Raum, und sorgen dabei für einiges an Abwechslung (visuell zumindest).

Durch den hyperbolischen und sphärischen Raum zu laufen ist vor allem am anfang sehr gewöhnungsbedürftig, da wir ja an euklidischen raum gewöhnt sind...
Ich konnte aber nach etwa 10-15 Minuten heilloser Verwirrung langsam meinen Navigationsinn neu verkabeln und mich auf die Umgebung einstellen.
Im Verlauf des Spiels entwickelt sich eine starke Intuition wie dieser Raum sich anfühlt und funktioniert...
Mathematik ist also absolut nicht nötig um die Welt zu verstehen!!!

Story/Gameplay
Die Zeit im Spiel verbringt man hauptsächlich mit reden, laufen/suchen (was tatsächlich fordernd ist lol), und Minispielen, die durchaus Spaß machen.
Die NPCs, die in der Welt verstreut sind, haben sehr verspielte Persönlichkeiten, sind teilweise ziemlich lustig und erzählen dabei durch Gerüchte die Geschichte des "virtuellen" Ortes Hyperbolica.
Diese beschäftigt sich mit Themen wie künstlicher Intelligenz, VR und das "Hochladen" von Gehirninhalten.
Besonders tiefgründig ist die Story zwar nicht, aber das Worldbuilding trägt definitiv dazu bei, dem Spiel Leben einzuhauchen.
Ah und für Freunde des Dating-Simulator Genres gibt es selbstverständlich ein Speed Dating Event im Infinity Café, 19 uhr, nicht verpassen!

Fazit
jup, dieses spiel würd ich definitiv empfehlen, allein schon weil es so einzigartig ist!
Navigation neu zu lernen und in so etwas simplen wieder gefordert zu werden ist etwas echt neues, und sehr komisches...
Faszination wird hier groß geschrieben, würd ich sagen!
außerdem sind die Vibes in diesem spiel einfach am Staarrt, wenn ihr wisst was ich meine freunde

Wer allerdings mit der Erwartung hineingeht, einen actiongeladen-thriller-abenteuer-heist titel zu bekommen, in dem keine Sekunde ruhe ist, ist wirklich an der falschen Adresse!
wer die Erwartung hat wollte nach Berlin und ist in Brazilien gelandet..
wer die Erwartung hat ist jetzt auf dem Mond.

Also ja diese art von Spieler wird sich an das Ski oder Rollschuh-Kellner Minigame klammern müssen wie ein Ertrinkender an eine Schiffsplanke.

allen anderen kann ich den titel nur empfehlen:
kurz, knackig, raffiniert und frittiert sämtliche gehirnwindungen
AS IT ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ SHOULD BE

xoxo

Euer Karbontragödius Gervolteronkler (
me[kartonrad.de] )
 
Kartonrad

Non recommandé
7.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 février 2023
Sadly I have to say no to this "game".

The hyperbolic geometry is fascinating. But that's about all.

Because quests in game are not fun.

In the restaurant area where player have to serve quickly. The game practically assist nothing to help this task. Yes it show a target icon to the next table. But if the player facing other direction, there's no way to tell where's the next target (an arrow at the edge of screen pointing toward the direction of the next target would be nice). Actually, there is no serving order, so the player may plan the shortest route to serve all orders (instead of moving around inefficiently pointing to the next target shown by the game). But the game really have no concept of this planning: stop the time before the quest start, look at a map and pan around, show multiple target with distances.

In the farm area where player have to shoot beavers. It's so tedious to hit a beaver. It is ok that standing somewhat close to the beaver and shoot make them scare and hide. But I moved backward some distance to the point that the beaver is large over the horizon. Why shooting them at this stage still make them go hiding???

In the snow area where player have to do a snowball fight against NPCs. Not only the mechanic is clunky and tedious. The more important part is it is unfair, 3 vs 1. Each one (including the player) has 5 HP. JUST WHY??? This unfairness can be compensated with the player having 5 HP while others have 2 or 3 HP instead. That's not to the point of fair, but definitely more fair and more achievable.

And, guess what, all of these quests are mandatory to progress the story!

I really appreciate the mindblowing implementation of this weirdly unintuitive geometry. But honestly, speaking of it as a game, at least get a team with a game designer and play testers. They can help weeding out those unfun aspects off the game. Or if you're really tight on budget, the release the game as early-access to get a live feedback from actual players. Don't let the game fall into this stage of colorful limbo. (actually, go see the global achievement stat. there's only 1/4 players completing the game. that's really tell something.)
 
neizod
570 produits enregistrés

7 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 mars 2022
A long time ago, YouTube recommended me a small channel, called CodeParade. The first video I watched was about non-euclidian games. Then, he decided to make a game based on that, and this is the result.
First, I must say this game is not for everyone, because it leans on many math jokes, and, unless you really like some weird... stuff, you may have a bad time.
But, still, I loved it! It's simply a puzzle game using non-euclidian geometry, but that's the catch! The puzzles are creative, the art is nice, the character are simply, but likeble, and the music is good.
The downside? Perhaps you get some seizures or headaches. I confess I had some headaches when I played the first time, but I got used to it. Also, the game is quite short, but I believe that actually was for the best, and the game didn't overdo thing.
So, tl;dr: If you want a inovative puzzle, and want some weird stuff, buy this game. If you like geometry, get this game.
 
man
517 produits enregistrés

6 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
1.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 mars 2022
I'm not gonna lie to you: Your eyes will hurt. You will understand the dizziness your grandmother feels when trying to play FPS games for the first time. Navigating the world and trying to understand how you're moving between places is surreal and fascinating, and simple story supports it well enough.

But wow, my brain physically hurts from my eyes trying to make sense of it all. I really hope that if I get enough practice, it gets better. The dev did absolutely everything possible: clean, simple art style, camera smoothing, the works.

My simple human eyes just struggle to keep up. Watching gameplay vids is totally fine, but it feels different when you're playing it yourself. I wonder if VR would be better; I feel like me trying to resolve the shapes on a flat render gives me problems. If I could see the depth for myself, it might actually be easier.

It might not be ground breaking (gameplay-wise), and it might not move you emotionally, but it does something VERY different and novel, and explored new frontiers from a technical perspective. It's a unique experience that is valuable to explore.
 
The Inventor

Non recommandé
1.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 mars 2022
Besides the main gimmick, there is barely any substance to this game. the world is full of npcs, but barely any of them actually have anything useful to say, but you are still expected to talk to them if you want the good ending. there is nearly no way to distinguish important npcs from those that are just filler.
In addition, there is very little to actually do. main quest takes little more than an hour, and the side content, if you can find it, more often than not just boils down to just listening to someone talk, which is a problem, because the writing is NOT good.

an interesting world, with barely anything to actually do in it.
thankfully, even if you aren't in a hurry the game can be beaten in under 2 hours

Non recommandé
2.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 mars 2022
Short version:
This game is not for everyone. Only for mathematics nerds.

(I wrote this review AFTER beat this game. It took only 85 minutes. I'm sure you can do it less than 45 minutes if you do speedrun.)


If you are hyped by CodeParade's dev logs and expect an average game, you won't have positive opinion.

Visual is like... alright. non-euclidean graphic is very new, more like very first 3d non-euclidean perspective game or something. (I bet most people will be nauseated by this)

The problem is... That's it.
To summarize, most parts of the game are like: "Hyperbolica is cool!" or way too generic monologues.

Game system is not completed. For example: You don't know what you have to do to progress the game. Nothing will reminds you unless you accidentally did what you have to do.
No task tracker. That demotivates me so much...

Story and contents aren't interesting at all. Felt like this game is for young children.
Then, is it really for children? I don't think so because of non-euclidean perspective view and the mechanics that require to think with this perspective.
Then, is it educational game? Maybe? But I don't think so. If it is, what is it teaching us?

I'd like to ask: What do you want to do with this?
Yeah, you developed a game. That's good, I know. But WHAT do you want to do with THIS?
 
James Karet

Évaluation publiée le 14 mars 2022
首先這可能會是你玩過最暈的一款遊戲。
hyperbolica確實提供了一個直覺的方式了解雙曲幾何，但遊戲內容有些平乏，操作流暢感也有待改善。完成度比較類似於有創意的大學生集結起來完成的作品。有鑑於製作團隊的人數，這樣的結果似乎也不是特別意外。
內容乏善可陳我可以理解，但以這個價格我會期待至少可以有舒適的遊玩體驗，對話不能中斷/快轉，跳躍緩慢掉落。各個關卡散落導致沒有一個整體性。

Recommandé
3.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 mars 2022
《Hyperbolica》是一款非常奇怪的游戏，核心机制在于“非欧空间”。

“非欧空间”这个概念非常难理解，我自己也没理解，但大概意思是空间本身的扭曲。空间扭曲了，光线就也会扭曲，那么我们看到的世界（投影）就也会变得非常奇怪。细节我真的说不出来，这个游戏做出来就是为了让玩家对一些非欧空间，比如双曲空间，有更直观的感受，但绝对说不上让这些概念更好理解。

所以这款游戏就是构造了一个非欧空间中的世界，让玩家在里面自行探索这些怪异的空间概念，并利用自己的理解来完成一些一般来说非常正常，但放在非欧空间中就会非常奇异的任务，比如走迷宫等。感觉不管是动作还是解谜，都没有太大的难度，关注点更多还是在非欧空间中的奇异现象。

除了玩法之外，本作还有很多NPC和对应的对话，其中大多数都是和英语双关或者数学相关的笑话，这个就看大家感不感兴趣吧。

总之这款游戏可以看作是一种对非欧空间的交互式技术展示，由于实在是太奇怪，我不知道该怎么评价这款游戏。如果你对非欧空间相关的概念感兴趣，而且不担心玩着头晕的话，可以试试这款非常奇怪的游戏。

（这款游戏居然还可以在VR里玩，天哪，在不晕3D的情况下，我看着屏幕都觉得头晕，怕是只有高人才能用VR玩还不吐出来了吧...）
 
OldCaptainWZJ
417 produits enregistrés
2
7 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
2.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 mars 2022
I'm a big math nerd, and seeing something like this in concept being brought into an interactive experience is always great to see! The game tries to take the concept of curved spatial geometry and pair it up with a story, which sounds fantastic at first glance! Unfortunately, the story is... well, let's just say the story is so shallow and slapped-together you may as well not even bother with it. As someone who's huge into lore and rich story-telling, this is pretty much a turn-off on all fronts. It almost feels like it's one of those games where it takes an idea, performs the idea really well, but then splashes a bucket of "everything else to qualify it as a game" paint messily without any further thought. I completed the main game in 2.2 hours, including one or two side quests, and the entire experience was (story spoilers!) "wow, the curved geometry is a really neat concept! i hope i get to solve pretty cool puzzles and all that! ok so i'm looking for shapes, don't know why, nothing makes sense, this blue guy just wants me to do it. oh ok now i guess i gotta talk to everyone to know what's going on. yay i did the thing. time to do it like 5 more times. oh, i guess i'm fighting a cheap knock-off GLaDOS but edgy. k i killed it. yay i saved everyone somehow" and that was it. It's a short little experience that'll keep you occupied for a little bit, but there's pretty much nothing beyond that. I would certainly not price it at $17 though, wait for a sale if you're planning on picking it up. Overall, i really wish there was more done with the curved geometry. it seemed to be far more in the background with the story trying to be put in front, which really doesn't work out well considering the story isn't... that great... feels more like a tech demo than a proper game.
 
Plasmawario
238 produits enregistrés
