4.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 mars 2022
It's a shallow experience beyond the main spectacle at the surface level. However, that spectacle is very fascinating and a treat to mess around with as long as you are curious. All the gimmicks pay off, and all the set pieces have their own Non-Euclidean quirks for some variety.

The concept/execution of Hyperbolica is something that is truly new and unique to videogames afaik. It's worth checking out for that reason alone.
 
yoel
246 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 mars 2022
I love all kinds of wacky geometry games, truly non-euclidean or not, and I've been waiting for this game for a long time and following the dev stuff.

I enjoyed this little adventure. It's got a fun, distinct style on top of the nonstandard geometry making things weird. It probably accomplishes what it was going for, but if Steam could leave a "recommended, but with considerations" review, I'd use that here.

I'd call this a surreal sightseeing game more than anything else, as there feels to be little of interactive substance here. The NPCs you encounter are mostly fluff without adding much to the environment or story. Despite the hyperbolic geometry allowing for surreal, expansive areas, the game world feels strangely small, though that's probably due to the game *not* being procedurally generated so the effort to make places larger and fill them up would be exponential. Although there's a couple puzzles, they run out quick as well. Maybe I was expecting more in the way of things to do, but wandering around and going "that looks cool" at the little details and having a chuckle at hidden memes was fine too. Still, I feel there could've been more opportunities to make use of the unusual geometry for unusual activities, but maybe Hyperbolica 2 someday?

Either way, don't let my reservations dissuade you if you're fine with a casual trippy experience; I don't have a VR headset, but I'd imagine it'd be even better with one. Commendable effort by the developer to make something unique.

[9/10] Jedna z nejoriginálnějších indie her celkem, zaměří na prostory, které jiné prostorové vlastnosti, každopádně momentálně ji jste schopni 100% dohrát pouze za pár hodin, což může někoho u indie hry za 14 euro odradit. Pokud jste velký fanda příběhů a gameplaye a nejde vám o zážitek z jiné dimenze při hraní, doporučuji tuto hru koupit až po nadcházejících updatech.

Hyperbolic and spherical space are certainly mind-boggling. Things don't work the way one expects them to work. Hyperbolica is a unique game I enjoyed although I wish there was more content. TMC
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 mars 2022
this is not a puzzle game, it's an adventure game with a few puzzles. that said- the hyperbolic (or spherical) geometry is certainly a mindf***. walking around the central path for the first time, without the map, WILL break your brain. even when you get the map, you really end up needing to use your brain.

if you get stuck, talk to the oracle- i managed to complete the game with no guides or walkthroughs which is honestly a breath of fresh air these days. he does stop just short of helping you get 100%- not sure if it's a bug or not, but either way it is still possible if you pay attention, and talk to every npc (again, it's an adventure game so you should be doing that anyway ;) )

i only bumped into one bug, which meant i had to reload and backtrack like 2 minutes. suprisingly polished otherwise, very well done.

Évaluation publiée le 14 mars 2022
The style is cute, the physics is fascinating. You can feel this was a labour of love.

It absolutely does send my eyes wonky, but the game tells you this might happen and to take breaks from the screen. That's a sign of care and respect. Good user experience.

I see this as something I'll happily dip in and out of. It's very satisfying to explore, and turns a lot of the rules of space on their head.

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
5.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 mars 2022
Such a wonderful and cute game, it's quite short but well worth the money imo. I ran into only a single bug through out the entire playthrough and it wasn't even a big deal. I very much enjoyed the cute personalities of the characters and the interactive experiences. Along with the cute aesthetics of the world the soundtrack adds so much to the experience I don't feel bad at all for buying it as I will be revisiting some of the songs to listen to later. It's not a hard game by a long shot but a very enjoyable one that lets you find fun in figuring out the world. At the time of this review I have not tried the VR mode but I'm looking forward to truly appreciating Hyperbolica's world as if I were actually in it. I really did enjoy this game and I would recommend it to anyone looking for an unforgettable video game experience.

KrachboomdukederProfi

Recommandé
5.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 mars 2022
Been waiting for this game for a long time, over a year. It delivered and then some. I could go on and on about all the standard things you see reviewed in games but what needs to be talked about it what this game could potentially do for gaming going forward. With Segerman's work on ray marching, I think this game holds the proof of concept that we needed to see a very large scale game made like this. Not knocking anything this game did. I loved it all. Great story, fun characters that made me feel, and truly the most innovative thing to gaming I've seen since Portal.

Évaluation publiée le 23 mars 2022
This game is... interesting. Forget what you learned in geometry class; it won't apply here. And if you think that you can just enjoy a nice meal at the Infinity Cafe, don't get stuck in an angleless corner. If you think that you can enjoy a walk around a farm, don't look up, or if you go on the other side of the world of the house, well, in normal geometry, you go into the house, but in Hyperbolica, the house goes around you.

12.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 novembre 2023
An amazing and unique exploration of hyperbolic and spherical geometry that absolutely bends your brain. It's amazing to me that this is even possible to even exist as a game. The experience was short (12 hours) but definitely well worth it. You don't need any experience with math to play this, just a puzzle-solving mindset; the game lets you explore at your own leisure and slowly introduces concepts to you that differ per area. The story was neat as well and there was plenty enough to discover. I'm pretty sure there's some secrets with the maze as well that I haven't been able to figure out yet.

Mage
1,209 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 13 mai 2022
Great game, and a nice break from the the euclidean geometry that's used in basically every game and even real life.

Simply moving around in this game is a pretty unique experience and the game's story is short but sweet. Many of the characters feel very well defined too. There's also some pretty good humour.

I should however mention that the game has some difficult parts that are required to progress. It lets you quickly retry these sections if you fail, but they can still get repetitive and annoying. It would be nice if failing enough times unlocks an easy mode, or if a crosshair was displayed in the sections that require aim. Also, moving around first person in a different geometry is not for everyone. It might make some people a bit dizzy.

Personally though, I found moving around in this distorted world really fun!
It's a cool experience.
Would definitely recommend.
 
S

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
6.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 mars 2022
I played this through in VR and it is certainly an experience. Some of the minigames aren't terribly well suited for VR, I had to play on desktop to finish the drone flying bit which is vomit city in VR, but mostly it's just wandering around and chatting with people and enjoying the insane scenery. It's got pretty fun writing, the story is about what you'd expect from a 3-6 hour game. I'll be honest, I can't really understand the mathematics behind the way the world is rendered, even after watching the dev's youtube series of making this, but I like the trippy non euclidian geometery, it's a good USP. My favourite level is the art gallery, it's really cool to walk around, just wish they did more with the exhibits, a lot of them are things that could be in any other 3d games, they should've added some freaky experiences like walking through a mobius strip or something. I'd say this was the best game of all time, but that would be hyperbole!!!!!!! (get it?)

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 mars 2022
I've been following the development videos for a while, and was fascinated by the idea of a game in hyperbolic space. The technical feat is astounding.
If this game were using euclidian space, or if non-euclidian space wasn't such an unexplored niche, this game would be bad, no question. I finished the game in 2 hours, I could very well refund it.
But I know that what I paid for is support for the developer. I hope they do their best to make their methods available to others, so that they can focus on the gameplay and not on the non-euclidian math. If I were them, I would look into publishing the hyperbolic/spherical geometry stuff into the Unity Asset Store.
 
jimmosio
359 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 mars 2022
Produit reçu gratuitement

First: I was given this game as a gift by a friend. Not sure if that counts for "received for free" but I'm hedging my bets.

Second: it's good. Short, I got 100% completion on my first playthrough in 3.2 hours, but it may well be worth the cost. The same game set in Euclidian space would be an absolute drag, but getting to experience non-Euclidean geometries while doing a number of different game styles was fun, in the same way that just picking up an object and spinning it around was fun and entertaining when 3D graphics and VR were new. It's got a maze, a couple simple puzzles, one *really* not simple puzzle if you don't know a bit about non-Euclidean planes, a drone race that will mess with with your head, and an art exhibit that's vaporwave as ♥♥♥♥.

As for the various areas, there's quite a bit, even if some of them don't feel too different. You don't really feel the difference between the hub area and the exhibit, even if they are different. The two that stood out to me were the cafe and the farm, which both use very different kinds of curved space instead of different degrees of the same kind of curve.

The good: the forest and the city
The aight: the farm, the art exhibit, the cafe
The bad: the snow area

The farm is trippy but tedious, the forest maze is entertaining, the city area really shows off how curved space works, the exhibit is alright, the cafe area is surprisingly easy and surprisingly hard to navigate, and the snow area is where the budget and ideas ran out. The story, gameplay, and comedy wouldn't be able to carry this game on their own. It's saved from mediocrity by being a concept game first and foremost.

Overall, if you're going to play it, play for 100%. You don't have to get all achievements (God knows I'd only go for the speed serving achievement if you paid me), but getting all the collectibles and getting true ending is worth.

This feels like a kick in the pants, but I can't wait to see what's done with this concept by better creators. Alternatively, now that the base work is done, it will be interesting to see what the same team can do with more time and effort spent on the rest of the game.
 
Icarus Dreams

Recommandé
3.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 décembre 2023
Check out CodeParade's YouTube devlog series about this game if you're on the fence.

Experiencing this in VR is mindbending. After playing for a couple hours and taking off the headset, Euclidean reality feels a bit off. Note you will need strong VR legs to enjoy this

Set your expectations accordingly. This is a game about getting to experience hyperbolic geometry. It's competent, only mildly buggy even in VR, has an enjoyable soundtrack, good humor, and a nice variety of very basic challenges, puzzles, and platforming - like N64 era basic. It's enjoyable for the novelty and curiosity, both of which more than justify the cost and time, imo

Ekarp
177 produits enregistrés
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
1.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 mars 2022
The gimmick is excellent and I'm in awe of the mathematical skill it would take to devise. This is one of the reasons I was a big fan of the creator's work and bought the game hours after launch. That said, it's not worth paying 24AUD for what is essentially a graphics engine. Hyperbolica feels, on the whole, very empty. It can be argued the game has a lot of content, in the form of readable monologues from interactable NPCs, but almost all of it falls into the trap of being humourless quips that do not assist in gameplay or provide a sense of depth to the world. There are some NPCs that give hints about direct game mechanics but these have the opposite problem in that they word their lines with all the directness of a signpost and do not even try to speak like normal people and feel out of place in comparison to the overfriendly flavour-text deliverers. I don't believe I ran into anything that could be considered to be an 'overarching story' so I find it incredibly bizarre that the game was so focused on making almost every character give some backstory about a world I could barely engage with. Given the tiring amount of prose, I am impressed by the lack of typos, however, I am less impressed by the lack of exciting gameplay.

Before giving up, I found my way to a barn where I was tasked with shooting about seven gophers wherein the mechanic was to shoot at a gopher and then wait about fifteen seconds for each projectile to collide. In this time you could not shoot at more gophers as moving around the map could cause gophers to change what hole they appear in and you have to be in a very specific place on the map to shoot at each gopher. It should be noted that shooting the projectile makes the gophers burrow underground, making them impossible to shoot for a time, requiring the player to just sit and wait over and over. Another level was just a maze. The fact that I could make a few more right-angle turns in a row without winding up where I started did not change the algorithmic simplicity with which I engaged with it. It was entirely too large and I spent most of it without any idea of why I was even there beyond "find platonic crystal". Also, the drone race doesn't seem to work with the curvature and I end up rolling my drone clockwise whenever I want to bank right. I did find this element of the game exciting but gave up when I noticed that, even traveling in a straight line, the other drone was much faster than mine. It is possible losing multiple times was an intended part of the game and it would progress a plotline with the very tiring drone-owning character the more you lose but if that is the case then I simply disagree with this style of game design.

I suppose it is ironic that in a game so fixated on pushing the limits of what three dimensions can do that every other part of it falls entirely flat.

This game would greatly benefit from entirely removing Cornelius or adding a "fully skip monologue" button.
 
gapriel
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
8.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 mars 2022
good game, but not for everyone. i feel like i got my money's worth despite the relatively low amount of content. really enjoyed the story and random dialogue telling it, really enjoyed just wandering around in and exploring the various non-euclidean playgrounds. really enjoyed that i didn't get motion sick while playing it, and actually kinda enjoyed that about an hour after each play session, looking at lines of text (like a chatroom, book, whatever) made them wave around a bit in what i'm calling a mild non-euclidean-space withdrawl. 10/10, exactly the game i needed, and the first game to make me really want to get into VR (i just played normally, but i'd love to play again that way).

1,953 produits enregistrés

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 mars 2022
Before I talk about the game, I really like the game a lot and I would definitely play it again sometime, I just think that it feels kinda incomplete and I'm not trying to hate on this game for no reason.

I definitely recommend this game for anyone who really likes impossible geometry games, although it is a bit short and some of the gameplay is a bit finnicky.
To anyone who is looking for an interesting story or a game with a lot of replayability, then you probably won't enjoy this game as much.

The whole game is more or less 5 short sections with some sidequests, which is fun, but it just feels like there should be more to the game, maybe revisiting the different sections to find different objectives, or having more unlockable areas to advance the storyling, but it just kind of ends on a boss fight with nothing else to really do afterwards. my main thing is that the game just throws you into it, and you can do whatever with no real direction other than collecting the 5 solids.

Over all, the game is pretty good, and the graphics are the best part, just don't expect a lot of storyline or long term gameplay.

Évaluation publiée le 15 mars 2022
I'm on the fence about this one. I love what code parade has done from tech perspectives on his youtube, at the same time the game felt like a tech demo with lots of dialogue strewn about. I will always praise innovation and commend devs giving it a go but I think it skirts the line of game and tech demo a bit too closely where the actual game portions have me running around talking to people.

Maybe it is because the triviality of the tasks doesn't feel like it utilises the hyperbolic space to the extent I expected it too but likewise this isn't like introducing complete non-euclideon wrapping geometry like portal or antichamber and even if it did then it would be too disorientating that it wouldn't appear "fun".

It is at the very least food for thought which is worth a lot in its own right

This is the first game I can ever say that NO-ONE has experienced anything like this before. The way it breaks every understanding I've had of 3D space while also remaining perfectly logically consistent is absolutely bonkers.

Even though I already have a basic understanding of hyperbolic space it's a whole different beast when you're the one exploring that space. Everything seems tiny at first until you explore and you realize how impossibly huge everything is.

100% recommend.

Onnox
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 mars 2022
Quite an interesting non-euclidean 3D game!
It is acually very fun to explore all of the different locations (my favourite one is the art gallery), and also try different gameplay mechanics like rocket skiing, flying the drone, etc.
It's great that health regenerates when fighting the last boss, but I also wish it had a little bit more variety in attacks.
Would also be nice if you could somehow tell the difference between just generic npcs and ones who can actually give you a quest or an item. Currently if you want to find all items you have to talk to every single npc, and most of them don't do anything apart from talking, so it can be a little bit tedious.
And even after you talk to someone, since there are quite a lot of npcs, it is likely that you would lose track of people who you have already talked with. Some way of visualising npcs who you have already talked with would have definetely helped.
Also since locations are rather large in this game, it would be great if you could pan and zoom map (although it's still nice that we have map in the first place). For example, when I finished snowy zone I wanted to go back, but didn't remember where the enter/exit portal was, so I had to manually search for it for about 3-5 minutes, which wasn't that fun. Having world map (and not mini map) would have helped.
Overall, I think this game is quite fun and I appreatiate effort of the developer of trying to explore some non-conventional geometries.
Pretty sure I haven't seen any other games that take place in the hyperbolic space, and this in itself is probably a decent reason to buy and check out this game.

harrymcb
371 produits enregistrés
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
1.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 avril 2022
Hyperbolica评测
虽然说笔者给了好评，但是对于笔者以及很多玩家来说，这部作品并不适合游玩。严格意义上来讲，这部作品算不上游戏，而应该是作者的技术展示。作者展示的是一个充满几何问题的世界，玩家前一秒接触的平面，后一秒可能就与环境融为一体变成曲面。因为之前没有接触过这系列的游戏，笔者对于里面的设定可能没有太精准的评价。
不存在所谓的游戏剧情，玩家所要做的就是不断的在六大区域中来回穿梭，寻找可以交互的对象。可玩性并不高，玩着玩着更多的是感叹作者的技术力，而不是在乎你和小人在说什么。而且没有中文，一边忍受着场景变化的眩晕感，一般又要集中注意翻译NPC的语句，可以说是非常折磨了。
如果没有对于几何的爱好，也没有对于大屏晕眩的抵抗性，那我建议你还是放弃这部作品。我认为如果游戏完全专注于谜题，完全摒弃任何故事的想法，它会非常出色。我在游戏中做的第一件事就是海滩任务中被诅咒的箱子，老实说，这是唯一让我感觉必须利用世界几何的事情之一。其余的只是捉迷藏，或不受益于几何的非常标准的迷你游戏机制。随着你的游戏进度，也没有足够的实际奖励。只给你一张地图，让你即使是丛林迷宫也超级容易迷路，我觉得这应该奖励一张地图，如果有的话。
有很多迷你游戏可以让你通过某些项目获得额外的速度，你只能进入那个迷你游戏，然后当你多次穿越世界时，它又回到了缓慢的移动速度。
欢迎关注我们的鉴赏家:走心评测 ←遵从内心，写出真实感受
欢迎加入我们Steam组:走心评测←点击加入，一起探索游戏的乐趣
喜欢这篇评论，也麻烦点个赞，让更多人能够看到！
 
raceway
1,815 produits enregistrés
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
2.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 mars 2022
The game has great graphics and music, but sadly the game design and writing is not at the same level. Most of the game sections that felt like playing the game were really barely games and never really any fun, and worse they didn't really leverage the hyperbolic nature of the game world...There were way too many NPC's who were hard to tell apart and seldom had anything interesting or funny to say. Other than the farm section and the ending the other sections were quite samey. If this wasn't a game from a small indie developer I would've refunded the game.

Anyone wanting to try this game out, I would say it would be best to go in with the mindset of thinking of this a cool tech demo and just enjoy the visuals :)
 
Donkeyhead

405 produits enregistrés
0
5 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
1.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 mars 2022
Produit remboursé

Vertigolica

After one step – literally one forward step in the game – I knew it would be unplayable for me. Maybe it won't affect you as much, but for me the motion sickness kicked in after pressing the forward key for a split second.

I wish it was a hyperbole. Heh heh. Barf.

I've been following the development of Hyperbolica on YouTube, so at first I felt sad that I wouldn't be able to explore the game further. I was aware how much work went into this unique engine, and so I decided to force myself through vertigo; I lasted an hour.

Content

Sadly, I don't think the hyperbolic stuff is enough to carry a game. There are way too many NPCs scattered around the world, while none of them has anything meaningful to say, so it's tedious to talk to them. The hyperbolic space is interesting, I won't lie – getting lost in this area was fun and confusing at the same time. It reminded me of Antichamber, which was explicitly designed to make you lose your mind. Hyperbolica does it naturally. The forest maze was a cool showcase of how mind-bending this non-Euclidean space can get.

But... nothing here really matters. I admit I didn't explore all of the game (I only got one of these cube artifacts in the forest maze; I only played it for an hour, after all), but I couldn't shake the feeling that NPCs are just filler content for this enormous space that you walk very slowly through. Items don't make sense to me (a watch in a bottle?), the quirky sidekick might as well not exist, and the dialogues are a chore to get through.

I also wish that NPCs had some indicator that they have something new to say. Some have additional dialogue beyond the initial one, but the system has something annoying in it that I didn't want to talk to them again, so I don't risk hearing the same monologue the second time.

Conclusion

I will probably never fully know what the game has to offer, because the motion sickness completely prevents me from having fun with it. My Twitch chat also reported being sick just looking at it for a minute.

It's unfortunate that I had to refund it, but maybe the developer will implement some mechanisms to counter the dizziness and it'll make it playable to people like me.

As it is now, I can't recommend Hyperbolica. Motion sickness aside, I have to agree with other reviews that at this stage it feels like a tech demo – a very polished tech demo – but not a fully fleshed out game.

Nubrozaref
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 novembre 2022
You start out in a classroom, with your teacher telling you about geometry... telling you the old Euclidean lies. You drift off, wondering (as mathematicians like Riemann and Poincaré did), "why must parallel lines be a thing?" Or conversely, "why can't two parallel lines out of three intersect?"

I don't think this game will win any Steam awards this year since it's a niche title, but I gave out my nomination anyway, 'cause I adore this game! Yes, it's quite simple (and very punny with hints of meta (that's "meta", not "Meta" (though there is full VR support for the daring)!)), but even as a mathematician I can feel my neurons constantly readjust to the spaces. It's worth the price of admission for the novelty of navigation alone.

More developers oughta dare to do something more creative with non-Euclidean spaces like these (albeit carefully, for rather obvious reasons — if it affects even mathematicians, imagine how it could affect everyone else).
 
The Sojourner
147 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
5.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 mars 2022
I really love the idea behind the game. To the best of my knowledge this is the first game to ever take place in hyperspace, but the thing is I can tell that almost all the time and effort went towards writing the code to get hyperspace to work in a video game, and not much of it went towards the writing, or the game-play, or much else. It doesn't explain much about the geometry of hyperspace so most people who play it will just be confused about why everything is all bendy.

Some of the writing is good. There were a few lines that got a laugh out of me, and the plot and characters all seem kind of cute, but it's not what I would call great.

If I could go back in time I'd probably still buy this game again, but just for the novelty factor. This seems like a great candidate for a reboot, or a sequel. I really want to like it, but I just kind of don't since it took me less than three hours to finish it, and I'm still debating with myself if what I got out of it was worth the price.

I didn't do everything there is to do in the game, but most of the things to do in it are talk to people. If you've always wanted to see what it's like to navigate non-euclidean space then this game still has quite a bit in it.
 
Tachyon Beam

2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
3.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 mars 2022
This is the first time a non-VR game has given me a headache just from walking around in the game.

The actual hyperbolic space is mega-cool, the gameplay elements suffer a lot. I wish there was more to do in the game and I also wish the difficulty curve was a bit more reasonable, it goes from childishly easly to dark souls hard.
The game is mainly dialogue driven it would be nice to have a quest ledger of some kind.

And if the items you collect are supposed to have a function then it'd be nice if the game told me what that is and how to use it, currently it's just a 3d model with a label in a matrix. Um yay? The game needs to communicate its intentions to the player better.

I think code parade should seek out an experienced game developer for help with the gameplay elements.

I don't regret buying the game and I hope there will be a DLC with more stuff in the future, without that I honestly can't recommend this game. It's trippy but runs out of juice too fast

Wow! I waited a long time before the release. I bought the game Yesterday, finished it today and absolutely loved it! : )

Although short, the game is very detailed. However, you will probably not discover every detail/secrets in the first play-through because well, the Hyperbolic world is so large! I'm really glad that the game deals with the Hyperbolic Space along with how does it feel to live in a spherical world. Besides beautiful geometry, a lot of art is involved as well.

This will show most people how nice can mathematics be if you get deep enough the rabbit hole. Who knows, maybe you would get more interested in math because of the game; Indeed, follow the devlogs of the creator in YouTube (Code Parade) to get a better grasp of what's going on. On the other hand, for those who are mathematicians, this will be a very nice and memorable experience!

If in later updates, workshop items could be added, it will be interesting.

In the end, What a fascinating work! Great Job!

Non recommandé
0.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 mars 2022
For those excited to play this in VR, best to wait until the game is finished, whenever that might be. I got up to the first quest I found, to scrub a window. The squeegee flew all over the place, regardless of how I moved my controller, and I was unable to do anything. Upon exiting the game, I found that I had to end the process to get it to quit. Also, for those with Valve Index controllers, expect the usual frustrations until community bindings are released that make clicking with the trigger behave sensibly - based on this, presumably Zuckerberg headset support was the main priority, so keep that in mind if you're hoping for timely fixes.

So to those wondering (and put off by all the youtuber fanboy reviews), no, this is not a game that was released in a working state.

ShnitzelKiller
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
5.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 avril 2022
Not very fun, but an interesting and mind-bending concept.

Like a lot of people say. The "game" lacks. The writing isn't special and can be cringe or uninteresting.
I ended up spam clicking to get through dialogue, just to complete the walk-sim-collectathon, but I didn't even end up 100%ing it, cause I couldn't be bothered exploring every corner of the world to find every trinket.

I think the game would have been excellent if it focused entirely on puzzles, completely scrapping the idea of any story. The first thing I did in game, was the cursed chest on the beach mission, and it was honestly one of the only things that felt like I had to utilise the world's geometry. The rest of it is just hide and seek, or pretty standard mini game mechanics that don't benefit from the geometry. There's also not enough real rewards as you progress. A map is given to you outright making even the jungle maze super simple to navigate, which I feel like that should have rewarded a map, if anything.
There's a good amount of the minigames that give you extra speed through some item, that you only get in that minigame, then it's back to slow movement as you go across the world several times.

I came to the game with medium to low expectations and only really wanted to get it to check out the non-euclidian space, which was neat, but definitely not worth the full price for one person.
I can only recommend it to people who have enough of an interest or appreciation of the technical side, for a price like that to be even near acceptable. But even then, it's as good as an interactive screen saver.

Chicken
305 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 mars 2022
The game shows a lot of potential, although a lot is left on the table. I want to like hyperbolica a lot more than I actually do.

The game world itself is actually fun to navigate and get lost in and the art is simple but surprisingly expressive. However, it's unfortunately hard to find and stumble upon interesting and weird things inside of it. I never really felt like I could wander around and end up somewhere unexpected. I never really felt a sense of mystery, which is what you really want from a game like this. A lot of it has to do with the gameplay challenges and writing which are the two weakest points of the game.

The gameplay challenges tend to be either way too difficult or way too easy. Here hyperbolica feels like it's trying too hard to "be a game" - the platforming, timed challenges and boss fight feel very tacked on. They're all either too easy or impossibly difficult, just by the nature of how hyperbolica works and how players are able to interact with it. The drone racing for example is pretty much impossible if you have motion sickness, whereas the boss fight can be won by just walking in circles around it. It's not particularly exciting exploring around and finding these gameplay challenges scattered about because they're just not particularly fun. I feel like most players are playing hyperbolica to explore the interesting world moreso than they are for challenging gameplay. This problem could be ignorable but when combined with the writing leaves a bad taste.

The writing in hyperbolica shoots itself in the foot from the very beginning. The game starts with the premise of the player being in a secret world inside of a vr-esque online neural simulation. Over the course of the game we're supposed to notice that things are awry in this virtual world - things may not be as they seem. This premise sounds good enough, but is actually rather difficult to write well. How do you get the player invested in a virtual world? Games can take a lot of shortcuts when it comes to player motivation - it's often enough to tell the player that they need to save the world or fulfill a prophecy, but no one cares about saving a vr-chat server!

One way to get around this is to have relatable and interesting characters, but unfortunately hyperbolica takes the route of having all of its characters act mostly like terminally-online caricatures. I generally don't care about youtubers and tech-entrepreneurs in real life - getting me to care about exaggerated caricatures of them in a game inside a game is quite difficult! Some of the characters have humanizing moments but it's often too little too late - I found myself not wanting to talk to most npc's just because all of their dialogue felt either felt like reading a forum board or like canned game-advice about what the player should do next. Most of the time when there are interesting npcs they sound like insane people who act like the virtual world is real life. This of course makes sense after the player is finished with the game, but that doesn't make the experience any better! The exception to this was the speed-dating game which had characters with a surprising amount of depth and humanity and worked well with the game's premise - which is all the more unfortunate because it shows that the writing can be very good when the effort is taken to make interesting and human characters! Honestly, a lot of this could have been avoided if the game didn't try to "explain" its hyperbolic world with its premise.

All of this ties together with the main problem of the game - what is it actually trying to say? I really loved the initial theme about education by exploration but is that what we're supposed to take away? Is the player supposed to understand that wandering around, being lost is a joyous experience or is the player supposed to be focused on completing set objectives like racing or winning a snowball fight. Is the player supposed to look at their map and complete the maze or are they supposed to take joy in getting lost in the maze? Are the npcs supposed to be silly caricatures, satire of online worlds? Or are the npcs supposed to be people with real nuances, or maybe are they supposed to be cryptic, lost and confusing? None of these choices are necessarily bad but they need to be made and stuck to or else the game is going to feel more like a playground or a carnival than something real! After completing the game I honestly could not give a good list of major themes or tell what it was trying to communicate. I love confusing games but I don't like confused games!

I know that this was a lot of criticism, but I still actually recommend the game to anybody interested in exploring hyperbolic space. It is still a complete joy to walk around in hyperbolica and take in the surroundings. Moreover, I'm excited for what this dev/team makes next! It should be a testament to just how interesting and fun it is to walk around hyperbolica that it can stand on that alone even with all of its imperfections. Hyperbolica is still an excellent game despite its flaws and I think with some more focus towards thematic cohesion codeparade could strike gold.
 
advith
0
5 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
0.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 mars 2022
Produit remboursé

Certainly has potential to be a great game about Non-Euclidean geometry which isn't seen in many games, but seems to fall short on most fronts.
Firstly there's a lack of quality-of-life features like
-no left-handed mode, sprinting, the ability to skip through the endless mostly filler dialogue, or any sort of map zoom
-no way to turn off or change the ghost Valve Index controllers, and an uneditable control map only for those controllers
-npc dialogue that floats ingame right below your FOV instead of sticking to the camera, and no way to physically interact with the world other than clicking a trigger.

Secondly, the gameplay itself other than exploring the world seems to be various lackluster sometimes broken minigames
-The tool in the cleaning minigame simple phases through the glass instead of cleaning it.
-The drone racing minigame's controls are questionable at best, and there's no way to exit out of it if you don't want to wait the full duration of the race if you fall behind.
-The maze game consists of following a red marker on your map, but I will admit it was a great realization that it was made up of pentagons with five 90° angles.

I spent most of my time looking for cool experiences that have to do with hyperbolic geometry but instead dealing with clunky controls and rapidly hitting a trigger to get through all the dialogue so I could play a game.

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Non recommandé
2.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 mars 2022
eJ121's review describes my thoughts perfectly:
eJ121 a écrit :
To me, Hyperbolica feels like a tech demo that tries to be a game, but falls short.

From the devlogs on Youtube, I know a huge amount of pioneering effort went into this game. I personally think the places where this game works best (a maze, a chest-pushing puzzle, a puzzle involving some gophers) are puzzle scenarios where the game has the non-euclidean aspect of the geometry baked into the problem or the solution, and I think that's what a lot of people, hearing about this game, watching the devlogs explaining all the (many!) interesting side-effects that were unique to non-euclidean spaces, were hoping for.

Unfortunately, a lot of this game's content could be done perfectly well (if not better) in euclidean geometry, and seems to have simply been adapted to non-euclidean geometries because it can be, which leaves a somewhat directionless and bland end result. The blandness continues in the NPCs, of which most just give flavour text as dialogue (only a small number are actually relevant to the plot, few have much personality) and the story, which mostly amounts to a giant multi-step fetch quest.

What this means is that the asking price (£13.49 at the time of writing) is being charged for a (admittedly technologically impressive) rendering engine, a very small number of interesting puzzles, and a bunch of filler content. (The game can be beaten in a couple hours, this should paint a picture of how much actual gameplay is being paid for here.)

I unfortunately find it hard to believe that is worth it, so I sadly cannot recommend this game to others.
 
Lumos
276 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
2.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 mars 2022
More of a tech demo than a game. The dialogue was extremely clunky and takes up way more time and space than it needs. It really didn't feel like the hyperbolic geometry added anything to the game - take it away, and the game is entirely unremarkable, its 5 quests each incredibly simple and with no interconnection. Only the maze 'challenge' is at all altered by taking place inside negative curvature, and this is the least interesting of the challenges otherwise. The assets are incredibly repetitive and simple, and the pentagonal 'grid' system leaves a deep footprint on the entire world, making it feel almost procedural, despite being hand-crafted.

At under 3 hrs of gameplay, it is absolutely not worth its current price point. It would be nice to see something more interesting done with the concept, but perhaps the potential simply isn't there.

1.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 mars 2022
After following this game for 2 years and buying it on release was it worth it? Kinda

While the navigating all of the geometries was extremely cool, the puzzles mostly just devolved into fetch quests and platforming. I wish more puzzles were built around the weird geometries like the hyperbolic maze, cursed pirate chest puzzle, and the gopher puzzle. The game is extremely short, the main story should take you around 2 hours. At the time of the review i did not look through a lot of the optional content.

I did enjoy myself but i would recommend getting it on sale.

631 produits enregistrés

2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
2.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 mars 2022
As a math nerd, I loved what this game had to offer. The puzzles were fun, the world was trippy, and everything followed the laws that made me interested in this game in the first place. Really, I was super impressed with the engine and the design of a whole new type of puzzle game. I've been looking forward to the game for a while now, ever since I first heard about it from a reddit post. My little math-nerd heart loved exploring a hyperbolic world and collecting the platonic solids.

I can't however recommend this for full sticker price. I finished the game in its entirety in 2.5 hours, and the plot that drove it was pretty lacking. Concept was super well done, and this opens the door to all sorts of great things. But the game itself is pretty neat at best.

This is another case where I really wish Steam had a neutral review option. If the game is on sale, pick it up for a few hours of mind-boggling fun.

I'm gonna be honest, while I was very interested in the lore, the story as a whole was really nothing special but the game is a fun adventure through non-euclidean geometry with a bunch of charming NPCs that made it fun to adventure around in.

Maybe it's just because it's a one of a kind experience and I'm a math nerd but I really enjoyed this game.

221 produits enregistrés

2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
0.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 mars 2022
Very cool graphics.

The actual gameplay though is horrible.
If you want good, fun, satisfying gameplay, do not play this game.

Finding your way around is very hard, not because of the hyperbolic geometry but just because of how useless the NPCs are. You'd expect NPCs to guide you to interesting puzzles but most of them just spew out useless small talk (Literally 90% of all NPCs are useless).

Even the oracle, the NPC that is supposed to help you get to somewhere interesting, is very vague and provides near useless clues. You'll spend maybe an hour looking for a puzzle or an NPC that will help you but you get no where.

Many puzzles are not even that interesting. The first puzzle I found was a puzzle where you have to orient a chest into a hole by pushing it. It took me 20 minutes to line it up properly even though I already knew how to solve the puzzle.
The second was one where you had to shoot a mole that went underground if you got close or shot at it. I tried doing that puzzle for 15 minutes before giving up. I couldn't find any clues or figure that one out myself.

I've been following this game on Youtube for the past year or so and I'm pretty disapointed. 20 CAD could've been used on a game with more rewarding and fun gameplay.


 
MrPineappleMan
13 produits enregistrés

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 mars 2022
Hyperbolica isn't really a game in my opinion, I think it's more of an experience. But so far, it's definitely my personal GOTY of 2022.
There are a lot of funny moments, and a lot more math jokes than I anticipated.
I won't spoil anything, but the backstory really caught me offguard at first, but it's such an interesting twist at the end.
The only two downsides I experienced so far were:
1) The length of the story is only around 2-3 hours or so.
2) I was hoping the game would work on my WMR VR headset, but so far it's not compatible.

If you're into interesting worlds, math, physics, weird geometry puzzles, funny moments, and even if not, I would highly recommend Hyperbolica to anyone.

james2012
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
2.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 mars 2022
ive thought about it a little longer and as much as i do like what little i did play, im changing my review to a downvote.

its admittedly a bit shallow? its a great casual introduction to hyperbolic geometry but there arent many challenges or puzzles that actually take advantage of being in non-euclidean space nor really making sense of what hyperbolic geometry even is. the closest this game actually ever gets to a demonstration of non-euclidean geometry is the tedious holonomy puzzle on the beach where you push a rectangular chest back into a hole without physically rotating it. other projects such as hyperrogue (admittedly the only other game im aware of that utilizes actual noneuclidean space) do a much better job of taking advantage of noneuclidean space to create interesting challenges and puzzles.

and this isnt much of an issue to me personally since i wasnt really playing for story in the first place, but the story is kind of meh and none of the characters are very interesting, despite it seeming like the game wants me to care about the characters at least a little bit.

with that said, as a positive i do like the artstyle and visual design, and despite not doing anything to demonstrate hyperbolic space (besides letting you explore a little more) i did enjoy minigames like the infinity cafe and the drone race, the museum was especially very cool to look around in. and i did enjoy the visualization of the spherical farm town, though i wish it did a better job explaining what spherical space is to people unfamiliar with it. music is good also :)

i also dont think length is an issue, im surprised a lot of people expected this game to be huge. its a short game, and thats perfectly fine. i moreso have a problem with it not being as interesting or fun as i had hoped in that short length of time.

I played this game for 43 minutes and it gave me terrible motion sickness that lasted for days. I can't even look at a screen shot of the game without it making me feel sick now that I've played it. I was really looking forward to this game but I don't think I'll ever play it again.
 
Legendary Sideburns
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
1.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 mai 2022
Смотрел девлоги был заинтересован ждал игру. Задумка выглядела интересно и неевклидовая геометрия в целом интересная тема.
По итогу сама игра не стоит того совсем.
Во первых игра крайне дезориентирующая и это ожидаемо. С миникартой в целом проблема решается но в начале у тебя нет миникарту и ее нужно найти и получить. И это как-бы не легко.
Во вторых невозможно играть долго из-за постоянной тошноты, комбинация неотзывчевого управления передвижением и камерой а так-же непривычной геометрии работают получше качки на корабле. Боюсь представить что там в VR
В тертьих, и что более важно, игра никак (почти) не реализует свою геометрию. Лабиринт? Да немного сложнее но не особо интерестно. Гонка на дронах? Просто гоночка с самым отвратительным упралением что я встречал. Разнос заказов в ресторане? А при чем тут геометрия? Видишь маркер бежишь к нему. всё.
В четвертых, отваратительное управление в целом. Локации из-за изгиба пространства очень не маленькие и просто обходить из задача не из легких, скорость движения близкая к нулю не помогает. Камера которая всегда движется слишком медленно и плавно. В ресторане тебя "ставят на ролики" что увеличивает скорость но дает инертность движению что в целом неплохо. Плохо что при движении все вокруг дергается. В гонке на дронах направление камеры диктует направление полета и... ЗАЧЕМ? это сделано просто будто намеренно максимально неприятно. Я не знаю смогу ли специально придумать худший вариант упавления. Малые движения не учитываются а большие слишком сильно меняют направление и это все при том что нет возможности осмотреться без того чтобы развернуть куда-то этот неуправляемый "дрон". (ип росто хочу обозначить как человек который умеет управлять коптером, они управляются совсем не так, впрочем это игра)
И наконец в пятых. Игра просто сырая. Она выглядит работает и ощущается как прототип который забыли доделать. Декстуры хитбоксы анимации загрузки поведение проедметов и еще многие крупные и мелкие детали. Никакх притензий если б это был ранний доступ но мне кажется это не он.

Я ждал многого от этой игры и мне было интересно наблюдать за ее разработкой. Ждал зря.

Évaluation publiée le 17 mars 2022
I think the game is very different to any other game I've played before. The level of detail and amount of thought that went into creating this game is unreal. Although the game is very fun, I have a hard time playing this game for more than 20 minutes at a time because I get so nauseated by the hyperbolic geometry. Nonetheless, I will continue playing to explore the game simply because it is so entertaining and mind boggling. I've been following Code Parade's Youtube channel and his itch.io page for his games based on fractals for about 2 years now, so my opinions are biased of course. If Code Parade ever sees this, I want him to know he sparked my interest in math and has kept me infinitely curious. Thanks.
 
Compressor
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 mars 2022
I loved this game.
I do agree with a lot of other reviews in that there's not much unique gameplay per say and not too many puzzles which utilise the unique geometry of this game. There's a lot of going around and just talking to NPCs in a simple lighthearted world.

That being said, just spending time in this utterly unique and thrilling geometry was exactly what I was hoping it would be. This game isn't like Portal or Antichanmber filled with cheap teleportation tricks, it's totally new and fascinating. I spent a lot of time just trying to wrap my head around how everything worked spatially. I think by the end I started to get the hang of it, but it's still so perplexing to walk in a straight line, yet be walking around certain objects. You can take 5 left turns on a flat open plane and still not complete a full circle depending on how far you walk. The spherical geometry was especially fascinating to me and I keep coming back to that area to play around with it. After playing this game for an hour, regular geometry feels weird for a while and I see Hyperbolica when I close my eyes. I'm certain I will play this many more times and show it to friends and family to see their reaction.

Not so much of an engaging gamplay experience, but well worth the unique tour through a completely new way of perceiving space like you've never seen in a game before

Évaluation publiée le 18 mars 2022
While the game is on the shorter side, it surpassed all of my expectations. Despite feeling like a tech demo at times, the presentation and puzzles are where the game shines. The core concept is explored well, and the ending is satisfying. The music, too, is great. The character writing is surprisingly detailed and in depth, and the comedy actually made me laugh quite a few times, which if you know me is a big deal. Overall gameplay is fun, screws with your head, and controls surprisingly well.

Overall a great game, 7.9/10.

the admiral
203 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
1
Recommandé
4.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 décembre 2022
TL;DR: Impressive technical achievement. Gameplay wise, it resembles a visual novel with some minigames more than anything else. The game might feel short considering the price, but I'm still happy I played the game if only for its visual novelty.

Having never seen another 3D hyperbolic geometry game like that before, it certainly seemed like quite a technical achievement. The result is visually mesmerizing and my fears that it would just be one singular and invariable gimmick were dismissed quickly enough once I realized different segments of the world indeed used different parameters. If anything, I wish the hyperbolic worlds had been more dynamic in general: the last level (a boss) showed exactly this kind of potential with everything progressively reconfiguring itself between phases, and in the end continuously moving. Sure, it easily felt confusing, but in this case, I loved it nonetheless.

It should be noted that outside of the visual novelty though, the game feels pretty much like a visual novel. And on that matter, the overarching story is minimal: most of the dialogues consist of small talk and puns with tons of NPCs. How much you like this idea is pretty much paramount to whether or not you'll enjoy the game. I personally felt there was too much padding at times, but there were enough interesting discussions here and there.

There are a few minigames, some of which are funnier than others. I enjoyed flying around in a drone, not as much the snowball fight, which felt weirdly difficult for some reason I can't properly explain. Outside of the unusual structure, the visuals are fine. As for the music, some tunes are great but much of the soundtrack felt similar to me, so it felt repetitive after a while.

All in all, while I do wish more had been done with the structure of the world (its dynamic properties in particular), I still had a good time. I can't fault the developers too much for not having put a whole lot of very diverse content considering the team's small size, but it could be argued that much of the current price tag is there solely for the technical novelty. It took me about 4 hours to 100% the game, and a lot of it was me talking to every NPC I encountered (most of which are irrelevant to the completion). Regardless, I love experiencing new concepts, and for that reason alone, I'm happy I supported the developers.
8/10
 
Jesse Aidyn

Évaluation publiée le 15 juin 2022
Игра для людей с сильным желудком. Даже не в VR от нее становится плохо. Делать там нечего, кроме того, чтобы 10 минут полюбоваться любопытной геометрией (желательно с блевотным пакетиком рядом). Куча персонажей с которыми можно поговорить, но это тупо не интересно. Уверен, что игру делали талантливые математики и программисты. Но работая над уникальной неевклидовой геометрией в игре они забыли сделать игру.
На ютубе с комментариями разрабов она куда интереснее, чем в жизни. Блин, она даже по меню ощущается как базовая поделка школьника на юнити. Надеюсь, что разработчики сделают выводы. Знаменитый Портал тоже имел свой прототип с сомнительной графикой и примитивной играбельностью и вот как потом поднялся. Возможно и тут их пригреет под крылом студия или геймдизайнер, которые уникальные находки найдут как использовать в адекватной игре, а не в атракционе для желудка.

Flufferpup
293 produits enregistrés
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
1.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 31 mars 2022
Sometimes game developers think whether they could and forget to ask whether they should.
Once the gimmick of non-euclidean world geometry wears off you're left off with a stupidly simple game.

The hyperbolic nature of the game is a double edged sword. On one hand it gives you a wholly new experience to play around in and on the other... well...
Hyperbolic space makes it so the further you walk the more space is available around you. This inherent property causes any world to become a maze and as any good game designer knows, mazes are cheap and extremely boring to the player.
Coupled with the need to talk to every NPC to randomly stumble upon one that gives you a task to do causes the maze to become mandatory rather than an optional thing to be amazed by.

Walking around the world is tedious, there's no sprint and the walk speed is just too damn slow. You're lost half the time and if you happen to get back to a road sign you'll quickly find out the signs point roughly in the right direction and feel more like a middle finger from the developer than actual help.

Circular worlds on the other hand don't have this problem. They're the polar opposite. You can't make a maze with this world since no matter which way you go you always return back to where you came from. It's anybody's guess why the developer decided to use a circular world only once.

It feels like all the thought was put to the engine but only a fraction to what you actually do in the game. The game is chock full of minigames that are just way too easy to be enjoyable. It does seem like whatever was the first idea that came to mind was immediately put in place with just enough code and duct tape to make it work and then tested for a few minutes before moving on to some other drab minigame.

I can't with a good conscience recommend this game to everyone. If you happen to be a math nerd, go at it. It's fun to muck about for about half an hour before boredom kicks in.
 
zamp

RussetMantle
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Non recommandé
0.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 12 avril 2023
Wow, I really read a bunch of reviews and still got this game. Its really really bad. The tech is amazing, and leads to some really neat sights, but this game is just not fun to play. Steam Deck verified? No, absolutely not. Its got a ton of weird issues with text glitching and the map not working.

Despite being a walking sim it has quite a few "quests" in the game, or little tasks and mini-games, which are themselves pretty poorly thought out. There is no way to track objectives (like counters on screen showing how many more moles you gotta shoot), there is no way to figure out who you have to return to for quests (every character is near identical to all others except color swap and maybe a hat), and you cant track the quests themselves either. Some ideas are neat (racing through hoops a la superman 64), but major issues set them back from being reasonable (the hoop section's controls are just completely unwieldy on a controller).
It really just needed like another year polishing up all the game parts, cuz it seems the tech works amazingly.

The characters are also flat and uninteresting and all but that isn't the focus. On that front, what is there is about what I expected from the game. Also worth a mention is that it can hurt to look at for too long, the vertigo warning in the farm area was appreciated (but the way it was delivered is pretty bad, I just hate that character).

I would put this as a weak reject, maybe even borderline, but alas steam only lets me say no, I would not recommend this game. Watch the devlogs instead.

4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
1.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 février 2023
It's a one of a kind experience; I got some truly beautiful screenshots of an inverted farm, and the world geometry is really interesting.

But it's an AWFUL game. The "puzzles" have exactly 2 settings: tedius and frustrating, and the relative intensity of both varies, but never reduces to zero at the same time. Mastery of the environment isn't used in any interesting way, your movement is slow, the characters are slow talking NOTHINGS, and the final boss is easiest defeated by NOT using the interesting environment you find youself in.

If i wanted my friends to be bored, frustrated, barfy, and minus a faaar too many bucks for a tech demo I'd recommend the game. For everyone else, you'll get a better experience from watching a 30 second youtube clip of the game.

Oh, and it's got technical issues. Every single 2d object has tons of z-fighting; so dialogue looks like crap

Évaluation publiée le 30 juillet 2022
Honestly? The game is impressive for its engine work.

About gameplay and story? It just SUCKS. It consists of talking to 10000 characters and what they have to say, and for you to progress, it feels like you gotta talk to EVERYONE, cuz everyone has something different and some random characters just give you something random. Also, it doesn't really display to you whether a character is important or not, and it's just FLOODED with random characters.

The story is nothing much interesting and doesn't get anywhere really. Some characters made me feel like "oh, maybe it's not THAT bad" just for them to be used only for one mini "game".

Great premise, was really promising and was really well worked on, but it lacked a LOT on gameplay.

나 김두한이다
 
one deal is easy
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
3.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 mars 2022
tl;dr Tedious and boring experience that happens in non-euclidean spaces but barely scratches the concept.

I am a fan of non-euclidean games so my perspective might be a bit twisted. And it doesn't matter if they're truly non-euclidean, like Hyperbolica or Hyperrogue or use euclidean orbifolds. I like to visit places that are impossible in our world.

Hyperbolica misses the opportunity to show the beauty of such places. It throws at you various ideas through characters speaking but rarely makes it possible to experience them. In the end, it just feels more like an experience that shows how people with really bad spatial orientation function in our world.

There are maybe three puzzles/sequences that actually rely on non-euclidean spaces. The rest would feel almost the same in euclidean space. And they're usually not that fun. I enjoyed the cafe due to the movement that required a bit of predicting and... that's it. The drone race was a letdown, you just needed to cut corners to get an advantage over the opponent. The maze... With its size, even if it was euclidean, I wouldn't care about remembering it. I would draw a map though, which with hyperbolic space would be really hard to do. But the general rule of exiting such mazes works here (and is even mentioned by one of the characters you find inside the maze). The platforming sequence is so-so. Gopher hunt tries to give you hints (they get scared when you shoot and come out only after a while) and the solution doesn't make sense if it was real world but because it is an ecliptic space, seemed obvious to me: stand "below" the hole, shoot at it and wait, wait, wait, wait, the hole being "above" is actually the furthest it can be from you and gopher is forced to jump out from the whole right before the projectile hits it. Having to perform it 10 times is a bit boring. The snow fight seems to be as far as action goes in this game and again - it doesn't really utilise hyperbolic space much. The easiest way to win it is to get closer to a single fellow (by moving forward while strafing), spam it with snowballs, repeat two more times. And when I saw the mirrors... I mean, the mirrors and rays in hyperbolic spaces could be quite fun (actually could be more fun in ecliptic space as you could see them go) but they go the usual route (start from the end and just get the previous one, which usually is just one, to reflect the ray). I don't even remember other stuff that I did.

There are also other activities, besides already mentioned. You meet characters that ask you for advice. I couldn't care less about them and just pressing E/Enter until their monologues were over. Although I did enjoy a bit the nerdy cringiness of the rap battle. Even knowing that my decisions don't really matter.

But there are more things to do! Like giving the right object to the right person. Which is something that I really do enjoy doing in the games. Usually. I loved Postman Pat 2 on ZX Spectrum and lots of other games that had the same gameplay. But here... Here there are so many characters that it's really hard to tell which are parts of quests and which are there just to talk stuff. This brings us to the next point.

World. It's both crowded and empty at the same time. There are lots of NPCs. While sometimes they bring up interesting remarks, most of them are ignorable. But once you start talking to them, you have to listen to all they have to say. The "skip" button speeds up this a bit but it still feels tedious.

The reason there are lots of characters is the very nature of hyperbolic space. It's like normal space but denser. It has to be large as if it was smaller you would either not notice it is hyperbolic or the curvature would make it way more twisted (making people prone to motion sickness feel it even more). The decision was made to make the spaces large. And not only they are large but they are also extremely repetitive. Whole zones look the same. There are almost no points of reference. It's not like there are corridors or rooms that look the same, something that happens in the procedurally generated worlds, but they combine together in many different ways. No. Here, once you are in one zone, whenever you go within it, it looks basically the same.

The world itself has a hub structure. There is the central zone, which also has a hub layout. Mini zones at the sides of it lead to separate places. These places differ a bit when it comes to some space parameters with one exception of ecliptic space (which by the way is also crowded but also the most bizarre and fun).

My problem with all of that is that they're extremely safe with their non-euclideaness. Each world is flat, relying on squares (which in these hyperbolic space have five sides), not even cubes. While the space is non-euclidean, there are only euclidean structures in it. I understand that at least, at the start, you should have some more familiar environment but it's a shame that it isn't taken anywhere. Forget about visiting truly bizarre worlds. Forget even about proper exploration as all places are repetitive and dull. It's like walking through a large parking lot. I'd really like to try a procedurally generated world where each square (well, it would be a cube) is a different zone. Meeting sometimes random characters that would either require an item or give one and it would be up to me if I should help them or not (or which one to help). Even simple moral decisions would be better than cringy humour (there's one quest that touches the subject but you're more like an observer or a courier/messenger there).

There's also no real story. You seem to have an objective, to collect platonic crystals. Using a trope "to save the world". Why? How is that connected? It is somehow explained but I couldn't care less even when we were starting. Fun thing was that some characters (especially Cornelius) seemed to be aware that I don't care. I haven't even pitied them as they didn't feel like even trying to be real characters. They were there to throw a line or two and that's it. I was kind of glad when Cornelius seemed offended. Which is not an emotion I'd like a game to bring up in me.

Good thing is that the game is pretty honest with that and starts with an intro that you just want to skip to get to the non-euclidean part. When the character was falling asleep, I kind of thought that it might be because I was spamming the "skip" button (which actually makes the text appear at a speed that you can still read).

At least, it doesn't try to get philosophical.

Initially, I tried VR but the controllers did not work. I still wanted to try it only to encounter more issues. Like when you wake up, you're backwards. You have to turn around to meet Cornelius.

Overall, it's a disappointing experience. Good looking one but shallow. There's not too much to explore. Non-euclideaness wears off after a few minutes due to how safe it is used. Activities and puzzles are... Each person will find something they like. I guess that some people may have "aha!" moments. Gameplay-wise they're way too simple but at the same time (they lack any depth), some people could find them hard. The sound is okay. The music doesn't bring much to the experience, was getting annoying at some moments.

For so-called "non-euclidean spaces" Superliminal is a much better experience (or The Stanley Parable). For truly non-euclidean spaces, Hyperrogue does much better (has some really bizarre concepts, like "crossroads" where all walls are straight but there are still junctions, it suffers from repetitiveness within each zone but has more places to visit).
 
kotowate

Évaluation publiée le 15 mars 2022
It was okay.
I feel like the dev was afraid to use the narrative for actually talking about non-euclidean geometry, maybe because it's assumed the player is already familiar with the concepts? I eventually stopped talking to any of the non-essential NPCs, their dialogues got pretty uninteresting pretty quickly. Also for one achievement, you either HAVE to play the game in VR, or change code to trick the game into thinking you're playing in VR, which is pretty annoying for someone who doesn't own a VR headset. Overall not a bad experience, more of a tech demo/experience than a game, just wished the game TALKED about the tech it was trying to show off.

Alors je suis fan des jeux se déroulant dans des espaces non-euclidiens. Mais là. Pourquoi même proposer une version non-VR quand tout est optimisé pour jouer au casque ? J’ai vraiment tenté d’aimer, mais vraiment ça n’en vaut pas la peine si vous n’avez pas la VR.
 
Hanntac
647 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 mars 2022
Produit reçu gratuitement

I had a great time playing this game! Hyperbolica's universe takes place in a world of hyperbolic geometry.

While I came for the novelty, I stayed for the witty dialogue and immersive minigames. I found myself chuckling as I was pulled into the antics of some of the game's different characters.


As you progress through the game, you encounter a variety of minigames. The games do a great job of demonstrating unexpected quirks of non-Euclidean geometries, but they're also just fun. I had a huge grin on my face when I got to the snowball fight.

There's a lot of clever hints, puns, and references in the dialogue, which gives you motivation to explore the world and talk to everyone! The game's main plot takes around 5 hours to complete, but there's optional goals to collect and hidden minigames to discover. To explore the entire world and get 100% completion, it would take substantially longer.
 
frahs
0
5 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Many complains that it feels like a technical demo etc,

I'd say it's amazing at what it is.

We're spoiled in this age of gaming, by vanilla AAAs and incredible indie studios,
this is an even smaller project, and feel like it's worth every penny.

I personnaly wish the main quest would be better written, I wish it would be longer,
and this is why I 100% support this game, because I want more.
 
Metameat
291 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
0.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 mars 2022
I loved the YouTube dev logs for Hyperbolica, and admire the dev's commitment to pulling off this technical feat, but the gameplay itself isn't for me. It could work well if targeted towards children, and that's not an insult by any means. I wouldn't recommend it in its current state if you're looking for actual gameplay, as it felt aimless and frankly quite boring due to having to run around everywhere and talk to mindless NPCs. VR controls are also missing for headsets such as the Quest 2 via AirLink and a few others as reported in the Steam discussions, which is a bit disappointing, but there is a disclaimer currently that says the VR support is in development, so there's that, and I saw the dev address this in the forums, saying he's working on it IIRC.

My advice to the dev is to not be discouraged, you've done a fantastic job with the technical portion of Hyperbolica, and I believe that if you come up with perhaps another game mode that is more engaging, and not (please don't take offense) mind-numbingly slow at first, that'd redeem the game for a lot of people. I couldn't get myself to play any further than going around the starting area and through the jungle portal thing before giving up out of boredom, but I can only assume that the rest of the game is as uninteresting unfortunately.

Best of luck!
 
Xorberax

Évaluation publiée le 16 mars 2022
Games don't usually affect me like this but after playing this game for half an hour I felt dizzy, sick, and nauseated for the rest of the day. I can't imagine playing it in VR. I tried to pick it up again a few days later but immediately started to feel sick from the cafe. I don't think this game is for me, but I like the concepts. Just be aware that it can really mess with your head. For me it wasn't worth it and I ended up returning it.

i played this game for 18 minutes on ultrawide FOV on a 34 inch ultrawide before i felt too nauseous to continue playing. in that time, i didn't really find anything interesting to do and probably won't open the game again to keep looking. as a side note, i've never been motion sick from amusement rides, boat rides, car trips, plane trips, any other video games, etc. so the mind-bending is pretty insane in this game, play at your own risk.

4.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 janvier
This is a really unique and interesting game. I only wanted to play it for the mind bending non-Euclidean environments, which there is a good amount of.
However I feel this wild idea has been lost in the game, and a far greater potential could have been achieved if the age bracket of the game was for adults. This mind bending space, coupled with sci-horror elements and action, would be a perfect combo to create a terrifying game that would truly leave the player disturbed. Maybe a followup game will come one day.

Évaluation publiée le 29 décembre 2023
Good first dive-in as one of the first game in true 3D non-euclidean world experiment (hyperbolic / spherical). Can't wait to see evolution towards a longer game. What about hyperbolic 4D (not necessarily 3D slice of 4D), hyperbolic H3 maze (imagine a secret room hidden in hyperbolocity, a doom-like with secret passages to understand with hyperbolicity, 2-spin rotations (going around 360° leads you somewhere else like in Duke Nukem 3D...)), holonomy tricks, etc...

Loved it!

The story, art design, and gameplay of Hyperbolica are nothing special. They're functional, but that's about all that can be said for them. But the game is a very impressive technical feat. The hyperbolic geometry of the gameworld is amazing to see in action, and that by itself is enough to make it worth at least one playthrough.

Évaluation publiée le 9 octobre 2023
Was fun walking through this weird world. And fun to play a non-combat (well, almost non-combat) adventure with just puzzle solving and arcade challenges.
I especially recommend this to geometry fans like I am :-)

I would like more puzzles that can be solved by hints from the other NPCs. And, please do translate it to other languages. My kids would like to play but are not so good in English.
Some lengthy conversations were a bit annoying, though. But that's a necessary part of an adventure.

this game is an ✨insanely unique experience ✨ it feels like unlocking something in your brain. it made me realize the fact that space in the organization that we experience day-to-day is just one possible arrangement of space. i love how the hyperbolic space makes it feel like there is more space hidden within the space than in normal 360-degree geometry. very very cool and very very trippy 🤩 i hope so see more games use CodeParade's engine in the future, especially for static VR games

Voco
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 juin 2023
Non-VR review

The game cost $20 and can be 100% completed in about 4-6 hours with little replayability beyond a couple mini games. Which is short for this price point.

The main selling point of this game it's non Euclidean geometry in FP something which is rarely done. Which sets off the It's an over glorified tech demo alarm. But upon further review yes it is a tech demo but it's not over glorified.It's a pioneer in a new genre of non Euclidean games.

It will teach you math you won't learn in school yet it manages to not be the dreaded "educational" game.

Where the game let's you down is in it's lack of difficulty which leads into it's length issue. The final boss battle is pretty weak and a bit out of place to the rest of the game. The plot is serviceable but no more. I'd give it 7/10 a good first release from a new developer.
 
Glenn_Miller

Cornelius needs headpats.

9.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 mai 2023
Fun casual puzzle game. Some of the minigames (maze, lunch rush, snowball fight, mole busting, rocket skis, final boss) are just about difficult and creative enough to be memorable. The text adventure ones are entertaining to read, despite being entirely open-ended and hence without any built-in difficulty. Oh, and the map is super useful.

Definitely worth a buy. The game's only two flaws are that getting true ending requires a bunch of checking all around the map, and the lack of real newgame+ content. Thankfully, the Oracle exists... :]
